Posted: September 10, 2015
												If it's on sale, buy without hesitation!  If not... I still recommend it, but you should know that it's quite short!  That said, this game is high quality escapism and does have replay value (though I haven't done it yet and may not for some time).  It creates an engrossing world, pulls you in further with the great music--then keeps you there with its charm and a story that ends up...  Well, I don't want to spoil it.  I'll just say this: there were two moments in the last quarter of the game where I stared at the screen, wide-eyed, slack jawed, and said, "........ Well, damn."

												Certainly not a bad adventure game by any means. A bit archaic in some of its puzzles. Has a tone that sort of requires you to play along with how some of the dialogue is delivered, and is pretty charming when you do. Pretty fricking neat visuals. Can be a bit emotionally gripping, but not in a way that makes you feel alienated if you don't get into it, not in a way like someone who starts crying in a public place and you don't know how to react because this sort of thing doesn't happen often and you don't have context or empathy for what's going on, more in a way like a nice dog on the street does something cute and if you notice than it's like the dog did it just for you but if you don't notice the dog doesn't make you feel weird for not getting involved in its escapades.Also theres a naked dancing bear.

Posted: December 30, 2013
												S:S&S EP is an action, adventure, point & click style game with an emphesis on audiovisuals. Explore the beautiful realm, unsheathe your sword and do battle, conjure sworcery to solve musical mysteries. Just abouts sums this game up.I found this game to be surprisingly enjoyable little 'gem'. The music by Jim Guthrie, is one of the reasons that I enjoyed this game, the interactive/adaptive soundtrack and sound FX immersed me into the game, smooth gameplay and a very good story, the pixel style graphics grew to my liking too.8/10

Posted: July 2, 2012
												A simple point & click adventure turns out to be a bit more complex than it first appears. What you can do at any given point in the game is based on the current phase of the moon, but we're talking phases of the moon as they are measured in the real world, based on our system clock. Because of that this three hour game could potentially become fragmented across an entire month! Fortunately there are a couple ways around this. One is a secret mechanism built into the game that still lets you finish the game honestly, while the other is a click away but will get you a nice achievement tagging you as a cheater. Sword & Sworcery gives off a very dark and mysterious feeling and the great soundtrack helps set the mood along with the beautifully done pixel graphics. There are only a handful of battles in the game which are simple QTE, and the slang dialogue feels completely out of place.  Worth at least trying for something fresh.

												A game meant to be played for its music. The sound in this game is good and the music captures the atmosphere. There are a few quirky characters with some funny dialogue.There are several issues with game. The graphics are bad (ie. 2D pixle style), however that might have been due to the art direction that was chosen. The gameplay is simple and bland as you just click with the mouse to move,attack and select stuff. The storyline isn't that memorable either. You don't get to go to different towns (ie you just switch between a mundane dreamworld and a forest) or get different weapons (ie. all you get is sword and shield).If you like point and click games then this game is alright, else stay clear!

Posted: January 21, 2014
												This is one of the most insightful games I've ever played. It's not too long and the controls are easy to master. Boss battles can be punishing but follow the theme of the game. It's got the classical feel of a traditional rpg with some breaking of the fourth wall to show you it really doesn't take its self too seriously. The music is enchanting and in a way, plays a significant role in the story. It's not going to be a top seller, but this game is well worth checking out.

Posted: October 11, 2016
												I just got to play this game in 2016 and let me tell you, it's probably the best game I've played this whole year and last year combined. I've been gaming for +25 years and I've played dozens upon dozens of indie games in the past years but SB:S&SEP is probably one of the most deeply affecting and wonderful experiences I've ever had with a video game such as this. Jim Guthrie has outdone himself with the music and the Superbrothers are freaking legends of game design in my book from now on. This game has made me laugh out loud, tear up and feel deeply connected to every single character inside its little charming story. If you don't know much about philosophy, psychology and the esoteric, some of the game's subliminal nods and messages will fly right over your head and may leave some confused. For me, the game was deeply reflective and had so many things going on with its symbology and aesthetic choices that I sometimes felt quite overwhelmed with beauty to be quite honest. I just had to pause and take it all in. Especially that magnificent ending. Nothing short of a masterpiece. If you don't play this or can't like this, I'd rather not know you in real life at all. (PRO TIP: You can use the Z and X keys as replacements for the left and right mouse buttons in battle mode. That should make things much more manageable with the bosses)

Posted: March 30, 2014
												Pretty unique game, which isn't especially easy to describe. Part puzzle, part action, part quest, part obvious symbolic initiation into the pagan mysteries, full of interesting music and charming sequences.Another instance of a seen-before idea, wherein the participants are brought to a state of intrigue in regards to a symbol of power, embodied in triangular form.Play only if you have an interest in comparative mythology.tl:dr- Game says search for higher answers locked away behind a symbolic trinity, I say no, but thanks for a neat adventure nonetheless.

												An interesting game, to be sure- the presentation tells you exactly where to take a break so you don't get burned out, which is neat- even though I ignored it completely- and the audiovisual presentation of the puzzles requires you to think outside of the usual point-and-click box. 												6/10 This game is special. I like the artistic style and concept of of this game. But the pacing is too slow for my taste. Progress is dependend on the moonphase in RL, which means you will have to wait for weeks (or months if you miss the full moon) until you can progress, if you don't care enough to change your system clock (which even is suggested by the cheating cheater ingame). Even ingame characters died because of boredom while waiting for the moonphase to change.. If you like slow paced and artistic games, give it a shot. But I would not recommend it for everyone. And get the tablet version if possible. It's a bit awkward to play on PC.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: July 16, 2015
												A slow paced point-and-click adventure with side-scroller elements, I'll be the first to admit that this probably isn't the game for everyone. But I love it.Reasons I love it? - killer soundtrack. Seriously, even if you don't want to play this game, pull up the OST and give it a listen. It's one of my favorite soundtracks to listen to while I study or write papers.- the dialogue is hilarious. I've read a lot of reviews which pit the writing as pretentious hipster nonsense, but I just don't see it. The game got more than a few chuckles out of me. I mean, two of the characters you encounter first are Dogfella (a dog) and Logfella (a lumberjack).  I dunno, it tickled me senseless.  - the Grizzled Boor. This guy is a nut, seriously how do you guys come up with this♥♥♥♥♥♥lol. Uh uhuh uh uh uh.- the pixel art style is deadly. The first couple of times I loaded up the game I distinctly remember letting out a few involuntarily audible moans of "cooooooool" - the gameplay and puzzles are directly tied to the actual phases of the moon. THE MOON. How neat is that? The entire game should, in theory, take you at least a full lunar cycle to complete. That is, unless you can come up with some way to alter the moon's phases yourself, you cheater.- the combat is easy-going, which may or may not appeal to you. It's all personal preference, you know?- the puzzles were challenging, but not impossible. Once you get into the rhythm of the game a bit the solutions will come easier to you. I'm a huge puzzle nerd though. - great for touch-screen devices, if you're into that.- it's refreshing to have a female lead, honestly. She's just trying to complete her woeful errand, you know, doing her own thing, being a heroine and such.  Overall, I'd have to say this is one of the quirkiest games I've ever played, and I sincerely hope you like it as much as I have.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 4, 2012
												Art, it’s a subjective thing. Whether a painting is a masterpiece or just some colour on  canvas is entirely up to debate. As is whether video games can ever be considered art?Superbrothers: Sword and Sworcery EP is art, plain and simple. It’s stunning, it’s gorgeous, it’s moving, it gets down to the bottom of your heart and invokes the deepest levels of emotion. Happiness, sadness, loneliness, fear, these are the feelings that have stuck with me after the completion of the Scythian’s woeful errand.And what an errand it was. Sword and Sworcery doesn’t really explain much. You’re a Scythian, you’re on a quest of some kind, you wake up in a forest and are pretty much left to figure out the rest by yourself. The game presents its story through messages that are all less than 140 characters. It’s all very self-aware, quite humorous stuff and it’s what sets the tone of the game, lighthearted, but with serious undertones. To say more would spoil the journey.

												    Don't fall for this one. Just an excuse to use some poorly constructed, hipster style pixel art. While playing this game, I could only imagine that the "gameplay," "fighting system," and dialogue were created by three 15-year old indie nerds at their lockers during the 4 minutes between classes. 												Quirky game (and yes, a bit hipster-y...but not too much)  with an effective gimmick based on real world moon phase (literally there are only, I believe, 4 days in each real world month on which challenges can be completed).  Very enjoyable atmosphere and music.  I finished it on the full moon, dude.  Which was rad.  This limitation about when it's even possible attain certain goals actually made it more exciting for me.  It was like in the days before the Internet when you had to wait for your favorite song to come on the radio.  Somehow not being able to hear it whenever you wanted made it more special when you finally heard it.

number of helpful: 5 of 9 people (56%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 11, 2014
												What a great game. This is a lovely ipad conversion of a short, amusing, yet subtly bleak fantasy tale. You play a girl who turns up in a forest, accidentally causes a bad thing to come about, and then must fix things, all the while getting to know the few people you're stuck in the forest with and your destiny. It's divided into four parts and carefully narrated by a mysterious archetype figure. He even suggests when you might have had enough by punctuating the end of each chapter with a sort of summary of events and a kind of 'until next time...' attitude. Even though the game is quite short, it's broken up into four of these easily digestible chapters. Having EP in the title, the music is obviously one of the centrepoints and Guthrie does a great job of stimulating an apt mood for the moment with some unusual synth tracks. There are things that might put people off - it's pixel-art, it's fairly slow going, sometimes the way to do some of the puzzles is a little obtuse, but the pace is important to setting the mood, the weird puzzles further fit with the unique nature of the game, and the humour is great, with regular comments from "you" and others that tend to look at situations sideways and often break the fourth wall. It's a lovely tale to see, hear and play and more people should experience the whole of this.

number of helpful: 7 of 13 people (54%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: November 18, 2014
												Superbrothers: Sword & Sworcery, while linear, proves to be over-the-top and out-of-the-box.  While fitting into the pixelated art style that is becoming more popular by the minute, this game may be the only one to pull it off in such a gorgeous and vivid way.  Bright colors, unique environments, and the cute little creatures of the forest are all implemented perfectly and without excess noise to drown everything out.  The graphical content of this game never ceases to disappoint.  From a tiny village, to a waterfall going through the middle of the woods, and even a concert venue with a bear, Capybara makes everything work and keep you wanting more.Sword & Sworcery tells the tale from a Scythian woman’s point of view as she steals a tome and proceeds to fight a towering specter, numerous small triangles that form a larger triangle, and even that mysterious bear inside a tree that is much bigger on the inside. Using the tome to read your, and everyone else’s, thoughts from second person, this title provides a fun and humorous way to keep you coming back. While this game is short, it is split into sections.  To prolong this game, I recommend playing each session on a different day.  As short as it may be, Sword & Sworcery is a fantastic game with a wonderful soundtrack and is for anyone who likes adventure, pixel-art, art in general, or just having a good time.

content:
Posted: March 1, 2014
												Hello!I've just finished this funny little game, and so I return here to write a small review.I've bought this one off the Steam-Sales, after reading about the concept of the game and seeing a few screenshots.Ever since then I've been keeping this game in mind. I've finished it without cheating (Which means it can only be finished over a timespam of min 15, max 29 days, in my case somewhat halfway).I must say, this game is neat, fun and it makes you wonder... In general :)I don't really want to spoil stuff for people who're looking for this game, but I can recommend it for 100%!The graphics are very mesmerizing, and same goes for the comments most of the characters make.It isn't overdone, it isn't underdone. It's witty, the concept is really simple, and result is really epic.The musical component is just as big as promised, with puzzles and possibilities in plenty.Go and get this.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 5, 2014
												Superbrothers: Sword and Sworcery EP is a good game with questionable implementation.The game is a point-and-click adventure game with a heavy emphasis on music and stylistic pixel art graphics. The story is told more via a narrator character and through reading the minds of NPCs as opposed to through other means in the game. For a point and click adventure it's rather engaging, but more from an exploration perspective than from a plot perspective. The puzzles, by and large, can be a little obtuse, and the combat is simple. Some of the puzzles in the game involve the moon's phase (although there's an in-game shortcut which allows you to bypass having to wait for two weeks).Basically, I enjoyed this game, but at times it seemed like that was in spite of the game, not because of it. The mechanics and playstyle are probably better suited to a tablet (which I believe this game was originally for), but if you enjoy adventure games, it's probably a good purchase.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 6, 2014
												I enjoyed playing Superbrothers, but it was the kind of game I only wanted to play for thirty minutes at a time. That might have more to do with the genre than the game itself, though.The best part is undoubtedly the music. The delivery is good too; just experiencing the world is half of what the game is. Visually it is hit and miss; the pixel art looks great however there are often parts that are too detailed and stand out for it, such as the sprites. And the combat reminded me of Quest for Glory, which I enjoyed. The game doesn't try to hold your hand too much, thankfully, but reading over the Megatome can always put you on the right path (and adds to the experience besides). What I didn't like was the very obvious touchpad controls. They work completely fine, but the game could have been made more enjoyable with better mouse control rather than just substituting the mouse pointer for a finger. Also the blatant twitter integration was groan-worthy... but I could accept it with the way they presented all of the dialogue.Ultimately I'd say that if you are interested in Superbrothers that you should try to catch it on sale. It is good, but completely skippable.

content:
Posted: February 17, 2014
												This is a very unique and polished indie game. From booting up the game you can instantly tell it is going to be quite a different experience. Every aspect of this game feels very....indie. The music is indie, the art is indie, hell. its an indie game! The music is just fantastic. The game comes with the music files ready to be imported into itunes so if you this music is your cup of tea, you can listen to it on the go. The game takes moments to laugh at itself which I though was great and with the sparatic randomness, you never really know what to expect in the next area. The game is split up into 4 parts which makes it much easier to play through by making actual times for you to take breaks if you wish. Now the story is not entirely gripping and the barebones gamplay is not complex at all. The humor will make you smile and the purity of the game will make your smile wider. The boss fights can be somewhat frustrating but you will establish a rhythm and beat them in no time. You could buy this game for the soundtrack alone its so good. I give this game an 8/10 and a high recommendation to anyone who likes  indie games and games with a very unique artstyle. You will get your money's worth.

content:
Posted: March 29, 2014
												They say that less is more - that is exactly the case of S:S&S."Simplified" pixel graphics are executed in way that cannot be described by any other words but artistic and absolutely breathtaking.Storyline, while being in a sense simple, too, will soon absolutely capture all of your attention - and fantasy, I might add.Not to mention the mindblowing soundtrack that I could listen to for eternity, sympathetic humor (I feel like I need to make a point out of the fact that while the game knows how to be amusing, it also knows how to get properly grim), puzzles that are complicated just enough to confuze you for a little while, but not so much that you would end up battling them for weeks......all in all, wonderful adventure that you will gladly return to several times, just for the oh-so-strong feeling of pursuing actual quest and overcoming obstacles, obtaining power - and bearing the burden that comes with it.Absolutely brilliant. If only there were more games like that!WE WROTE A REVIEW AND WE FELT SUPERSMART

content:
Posted: February 4, 2013
												Superbrothers Sword & Sworcery EP is a short game by level design. There are 4 "levels" but each one has a set amount of time it might take. The first 2 levels are sort of short, but the third one is LONG, could take a whole lunar month to complete. This game is a point and click game as well, and the game has alot of character. You play a girl character, who has to go on a quest to retrieve some book, and once you get the book, all heck breaks loose. This game has a deep story, which might not be easy to understand at first. The visuals are great, all look great. There are so many visual elements in this game, it looks really fantastic. The audio is great too, done by a great muscian, and I actually purchased and burned the EP onto CD to listen to at home. The game can be challenging to find and figure out all the puzzles and levels, but this game is worth it, sort of short in terms of content, but like I said, if you don't cheat, it will take at least one lunar month to complete.

content:
Posted: February 20, 2016
												This is an absolutely lovely game. The art is beautiful, the music is great, and the writing is clever and silly in just the right ways. This does things narratively that few games pull off well.Because it was a tablet game, the control scheme is different from what you'd expect in a point-and-click adventure game, but it works rather well. The puzzles are about exploration and observation, rather than lock-and-key logic and inventory management, which felt smooth and refreshing.Overall, it's a very pleasant, zen experience.The only complaint I have about it is how it pushes the social media angle.

content:
Posted: July 6, 2016
												I have yet to finish this game, maybe even barely started it, partly due to so many other things going on, and partly due to it barely fitting the category of "game."  I can already recommend this however, but like everything it is clearly not for everyone.  Some will love it, some will hate it, some will like it a bit, and probably many will either never get into it and/or simply give up on it like I almost did, a few times.In many ways, it is more of art than game.  And understandably, the people that dislike this, seem to miss that point more often than not.  Chances are that you haven't played something like this before, and jumping into this can be more than overwhelming in various ways, depending on your expectations.  Your best bet, is to not expect anything, which can often be said about anything new, but it probably fits this more than usual.Despite the essentially awkward controls and playstyle (which may or may not apply to you,) it has a pull to it, so rarely found.  Simply keep in mind that without real hand-holding, it will guide you on the journey, with some goofy/witty commentary and tweetability, mixed among the stylistic approach at story-telling via multiple dynamic blendings and clashings of various types of art, music, characterization, and lore.It's an indie game from years ago, if you aren't up for the risk of adventure, get it on sale and enjoy it anyway, especially at your own pace.

number of helpful: 4 of 8 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 29, 2014
												The following is from: http://ricepixel.blogspot.jp/2014/10/ss-superbrothers-sexual-satisfying.htmlI don't use twttier and this game's nudgings to do so weren't strong enough.  The game Swuperbwothers: Sword and Sworcery had a unique take on marketing by having a built in node one could tap to automatically tweet whatever was happening in the game to their twitter account.  To me it was more of a nuisance than anything else because I didn't care whether people knew I was playing the game or not.  Had there been a moment that I wanted everyone to know about then it would have been another story....but apparently there wasn't. Aside from the lackluster attempt to get me to advertise for them, the developers behind S:S&S did deliver in one promise they made at the beginning of the game: good sound and jazzy music.  This Jim Guthrie fellow made some solid tunes throughout the game.  Particularly I liked the tunes the flowed After each I defeated and retrieved each Trigon, while I was in the dream world during a full moon, and when the Gogolithic Mass chased me.The one aspect I was trying to explore while playing the game was the insatiable curiosity I had about how the entire dialog of the game reminded me of something a schmo would say while hanging with his other friend schmo.  There were modern colloquialisms, filler words, and then suddenly words that fit the context of the game.  After thinking about this for awhile I developed in my mind a voice that I imagined would speak this way in real life.  I imagined this voice would belong to someone who liked groups like Ben Folds Five, but also would watch episodes of Sesame Street simply because few people his age would do it.  A voice that grew up in the 90's with a tinge of modern hipster.  And then I heard this.  ALL MY ASSUMPTIONS WERE VALIDATED!That point aside, I also wondered if most artistic games share characteristics similar to conventional art in that if they reflect the personality of the designer then they will be much more popular (of course among people who find that personality type amiable). In the name of Buddha, Amen.Here is my playalyzation of the this gamehttps://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLYBJxdpXNnt5ajxbZZcIp6qmG6UYq7lf4

content:
Posted: January 12, 2015
												Simple click adventure game. Looks pretty good for a retro sprite game.  You play as a female hero who is trying to find these powerful relics sort of reminds me of a triforce from zelda, there are three of them. The game at first helps you in finding certain things.  But, later on it gets pretty hard and I end up bacially clicking the around the whole screen trying to find out what will respond to my clicking.  You sometimes get clues from the 2 people you meet or the ghost that you find. But it's sometimes pretty vague.  The sound track in this game is pretty decent and catchy.   The battle is simple as you respond by the game giving you cues sort of like a quick time event.  The game is very short but somewhat fun. If you're into a simple click adventure game give it a go.  The only con is that sometimes you need to go back in forth through out the map and that you dont really have a run speed to quickly move around.  I would recommend grabing this during a sale.

content:
Posted: September 6, 2015
												An indie classic that plays by no rules. The I-Spy gameplay and mixed-media graphics blend into a mystical and incredibly self-aware storytelling experience, punctuated with S:S&S EP's masterfully orchestrated sounds, courtesy of Jim Guthrie. The character of the world and atmosphere is well-contained by the story's brevity, delivering a potent and memorable engagement.This game only asks players to be a little patient and take in subtle details when confronted with an obstacle. Exploration and experimentation is often rewarded, and an inquisitive attidude will help players through the story.

content:
Posted: February 9, 2016
												A slower-paced game from the normal RPG. This game has pretty pixel graphics, an amazing soundtrack, and a good puzzle system. While the combat isn't exciting or, well, anything much, it does add a bit of tension. The story is pretty narrative-based, so don't expect much dialogue. The music, being the thing that got me hooked, is amazing. Well-done with very solid tracks that I still eventually listen to, it is one thing that will get you gripped. The puzzles themselves are okay, but unless you go against what you're accustomed to in RPGs, you will find yourself looking for a guide. Overall?: 9/10. Well done artstyle mixed with a solid sense of wonder and passion in the dev's work, this game, and its free soundtrack included, will keep you hooked all the way through.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 11, 2015
												I absolutely adore this game! The pixel art is gorgeous and the music is fantastic (I often listen to the soundtrack as background noise, Jim Guthrie did an amazing job), and at a play length of only a few hours the game is just long enough to leave the player satisfied without being bored by hours of no substantial content.The writing is really fun and has a great juxtaposition with the setting which I love. Even though the story is set in a fantasy land and you play as a Scythian warrior there's a really modern feel to the way things are written and characters interact. It's interesting having the main character (who, might I mention, is a woman! extra points!) using "we" instead of "I"; for example, in the beginning there's a part where you can examine a girl sitting in a field, and the main character says, "Far from the war-ravaged steppes of Scythia we met a dark-haired girl in a sunlit meadow." It's a great way of really drawing the player into the game! Almost every line of dialogue also has an option for posting to your twitter, I never used it but if that's your sort of thing it seems like fun.The controls can be a little weird to get the hang of at first if you're like me and don't bother looking at instructions, especially playing on a PC since the game was originally made for a touch screen. Once you get the hang of them though they're super easy. I love that the combat system ups the difficulty not by introducing new things to the combat but by simply reducing your health bar as the main character gets more tired and worn down. It's a unique way of creating more urgency without simply making the bosses do more damage, and I think it's a great way to play into the story.If this game is your kind of thing, I'd definitely check it out!

Also, the game is split up into episodes that provide great stopping points, so rather than doing my usual "Power though the indie game to reach 100%" race, I've been taking my time and enjoying it much more than I might have otherwise.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 5, 2014
												Superbrothers: Sword and Sworcery EP is a good game with questionable implementation.The game is a point-and-click adventure game with a heavy emphasis on music and stylistic pixel art graphics. The story is told more via a narrator character and through reading the minds of NPCs as opposed to through other means in the game. For a point and click adventure it's rather engaging, but more from an exploration perspective than from a plot perspective. The puzzles, by and large, can be a little obtuse, and the combat is simple. Some of the puzzles in the game involve the moon's phase (although there's an in-game shortcut which allows you to bypass having to wait for two weeks).Basically, I enjoyed this game, but at times it seemed like that was in spite of the game, not because of it. The mechanics and playstyle are probably better suited to a tablet (which I believe this game was originally for), but if you enjoy adventure games, it's probably a good purchase.

												This is an absolutely lovely game. The art is beautiful, the music is great, and the writing is clever and silly in just the right ways. This does things narratively that few games pull off well.Because it was a tablet game, the control scheme is different from what you'd expect in a point-and-click adventure game, but it works rather well. The puzzles are about exploration and observation, rather than lock-and-key logic and inventory management, which felt smooth and refreshing.Overall, it's a very pleasant, zen experience.The only complaint I have about it is how it pushes the social media angle.

number of helpful: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 17, 2016
												Superborthers: Sword & Sworcery EP is exactly what it's shown to be in the title, an Extended Play. Let's give it a listen.Well, dude, before we listen we need to think about what we are listening to. Superbrothers from a story perspective, follows the riveting and sacrificial journey of a warrior woman who isn't from around Migmi Taw. She has to place together esoteric constructs in order to defeat a dark force. In short, it's a tragic hero's journey through and through, but with a twist. During loading screens and within certain objects the game's administrator breaks the forth wall reminding us that we are playing a thought experiment with a twitter overlay. Overall the plot of this game maybe isn't moving or entirely grounding in solid logic, but it is very relaxing. It's a story that you will find yourself slowly slipping into just enjoying, even if you don't quite understand it all. In short, Superbrothers is thought provoking, complex, but most importantly just casually enjoyable. Compounding on that relaxing story line is the game's stellar presentation. The creators went the route of a beautifully detailed pixel art style and holy crap does it impress. Environments are vibrant and varied, begging you to explore every single inch. You'll move from a concert to a forest to a massive monolith in mere moments. Not to mention the environments show you how to solve the puzzles given to your character, which means you never feel completely lost or stuck. From a battle design standpoint, these locals are made for exploration and variable atmosphere not combat. Still no location in the game traps you into combat without giving you a chance to ready yourself, meaning that you won't die and flip a table. The game play in Sword & Sworcery is really the only major weak point in the experience. Originally developed as an IOS application, the game's touch screen control system has been poorly appropriated to its PC counterpart. So many aspects of puzzle solving, combat, and movement can feel uncomfortable due to the constant feeling that you’re moving too slow or that your keyboard is uncomfortable. It greatly detracts from the experience on the whole and it's a complete shame, since it could have been fixed by simply allowing the player to move using WASD. Otherwise the puzzles are nicely integrated into the environments, the combat system is simple and rhythm based (which floats nicely with the sound design), and the twitter integration is completely optional allowing your experience to be as public or private as you want. So now to the most important part of the EP, the sound. Superbrothers is quite literally the best sound designed game I have ever played. The tracks are memorable because of both their intricacy and connection to various areas we spend extensive time exploring within the game. Combat tracks are adventure tracks are bass filled and mesh extremely well with the timing based combat system. More esoteric tracks fit beautifully with the cut scenes and trigon collection moments. The music alone is moving, thematic, and overall excellently composed. And it doesn't end there; the sound effects in the game are excellent. Pounding waterfalls, light footsteps, water splashing, or logs falling Sword & Sworcery will provide you an immersive sound experience. So then to summarizePros:- relaxing and thought provoking storyline- breaking of the 4th wall- extremely detailed pixel art- highly varied environments- Puzzles and environment mesh well- Excellent OST- Excellent Sound Design / SFX- Non-invasive social media experienceCons:- breaking of the 4th wall- Poorly appropriated controls hinder experience- Social media experience?Now for you completionists out there, I would not tell you not to give this one a go. Most of the achievements in the game can be collected by just playing the game, or doing 4th wall breaking things like setting forward your device clock. But there are a few more difficult ones. For instance you must use the megatome to kill 7 rabbits. This can be tricky due to the mechanic never being explained, but don't fret. You only have a few options at your disposal so it's not hard to figure out how to accomplish this. There is no completion bonus for this game, but it's also not that hard to complete so just sit back and enjoy it.  With all this in mind I guys this game a score of 8.3 out of 10 and a completionist rating of Finish it!

content:
Posted: May 3, 2012
												I just love the graphics of this game. I'm just a sucker for pixel-art, it's crazy. That, and the game is just great. It's some sort of point-and-click adventure mixed with a couple of battles. The music is also done in a cool way and fits the game perfectly. Man, the music during the battles... don't get me started; it's lovely !I hear you ask; 'doesn't this game have any flaws then ?' Unfortunately, it does. The narrative isn't handled all that well, the game is quite short, and there's a lot of backtracking involved. Now, none of that really bothered me, but I do wish there were more locations. And some of the puzzles require a bit of pixel hunting. It would've been nice if they were handled in a different way (either make it more obvious or change the puzzle(s) altogether).Still, a very pleasant (and cheap) surprise ![Rating: 89/100]

												This is the first time I write a review of a game, but I just had to. I paid 1.19 euro (which is an incredibely small sum) for it and finished it. You'd say this should have been a bargain, but I feel sour after playing it.Initially the story, the mood and the style in which it is written is really captivating. But regrettably everything becomes so VERY repetitive, dull and eventually irritating, the same can be said for the fantastic music.I'm one of the few PC owners nowadays who owns a dedicated audiocard (high-end one), I have 5 HI-FI speakers in surround and it sounds fantastic. It really does, but after the first 60min you play this game you have heard everything so many times. This coming from a guy who still sings the Civilization IV themesong out loud.Please play this to the end of act II, that is the best place to stop and leave with a smile.-The combat is very lackingSome puzzles make very little senseothers are blatantly obviousSome actions in the world do not make senseEverything stops after the first 30 min, there is nothing that keeps this mysterious world interesting.+An incredible first 30min of gametimeInteresting character build up

content:
Posted: June 25, 2015
												People say it’s easy, it is.People say it’s cryptic, it is. People say the art is beautiful, it is. People say the soundtrack is wonderful, it is. People say the characters are one dimensional. They are.People say the characters are deep. They are.People say it’s inspirational. It is.People say it’s dumb. It is.People say it’s intelligent. It is....Characters don’t have to be super detailed to serve their purpose or be fun. A game doesn't have to inspire everybody, we are inspired by the things we find inspiring and those are not the same for everyone. A game doesn't have to be super intelligent or dumb to be enjoyable by everyone. A game doesn't have to make sense to be fun. Everyone has an opinion. What’s yours? Will you be weighed down by preconceptions or misconceptions that you read about this game? Weighed down by hype or hate? Weighed down by what a game 'should' or 'should not' be? Should you nitpick the game away and strip it of its fun? Or does the act of nitpicking make it fun for you?Buy it and decide for yourself. How can you know if you'd enjoy this game without actually playing it? We have a refund system now.And more importantly, relax, your woeful errand is just beginning, but don't worry it will wait until your ready.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 6, 2013
												Superbrothers: Sword & Sworcery EP is a pretty cool experience. It's mainly a point-and-click, adventure game with a few mild puzzles and a smidgen of combat thrown in. It relies heavily on a strong narrative and kinda, sorta delivers. I had fun, I guess.Basically, Sword & Sworcery is a retro, sidescrolling version of Dear Esther, except it has combat and stuff. You're an adventurer set out on an adventure to carry out an adventure. You generally succeed. There's a bunch of peculiar characters you meet along the way.There's a few easter eggs and hidden locations in S&S if you're into that kind of thing. The music is pretty cool. The pixel art is also quite nice, the environments are fairly eccentric, mostly.Oh yeah, S&S also incorporates Twitter into the game experience for some reason, but it's not necessary to further your enjoyment. I have no idea why it's an option, all it does is let you tweet certain phrases.Whilst Sword & Sworcery is mainly text-based there are a few spoken lines for some reason. Kinda caught me off guard at first but it was interesting. Yeah. That's all I have to say about that.The general tone of the game is quite whimsical and sort of reads like this recommendation. It's slightly odd. Sort of a typical fantasy setting but with modern forms of speech, slang, "cool, hipster" vernacular, et cetera. It's like being told a story by a pretty chill, arty-farty, pretentious twenty-something year old who kinda mumbles a bit. I'm not sure if it adds or subtracts from the experience but it wasn't at all grating, it just sort of worked.

												Okay, well, what to say?This game has faults, I'm sure all of which have been hit on by other reviews. There is a lot of backtracking, the point and click movement can be clumbsy at times, there's no character development and it's quite short.But you know what? It's fun, it's fun and it's quirky and although I steamed through it in an afternoon I recommend it if you want something relaxing to have a little break with. The scenery is nice, the music it good and the combat is actually resonably rewarding - even though it's just timing two buttons.I liked it and I was charmed, I doubt everyone will be but I guess you won't know until you try it.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 3, 2016
												The first thing that I feel must be said about this game is that it's closer to a piece of installation art than a game. On paper it's a point-and-click adventure with some short rhythm-based combat sequences. In practice the puzzles require paying more attention to the music than to their logic, the storytelling is deliberately bizarre and less relevant than the overall feeling the graphics and music combined will give you. If you're looking for an actual game, with logic, content and progression then this game is not for you. If on the other you're looking for something you can enjoy over 3-4 nights, with the lights off and a good pair of headphones then it'll be a great experience. It's like walking through an exhibition, with great music setting the mood and slowly walking you through it.

content:
Posted: June 9, 2014
												Just finished this game and I loved it! I played through this on my iPad, but I have to say that the PC version is much more enjoyable to me so far. I think this is a game that is best enjoyed when you're not on-the-go, so that is why I prefer the PC version. Seeing it on a bigger screen and hearing it with better speakers makes it much more immersive. It has one of the most unique art styles I have ever seen. The music is fantastic and I have been listening to the soundtrack frequently outside of the game. The story is intriguing. In short, this is a masterpiece and well worth the 4-5 hour play-through if you can accept the strangeness and just try "feel" the game and the music. They put a lot of emotion into it. Oh, and use a nice pair of headphones if you have access to some.Pros:*Even though it's a point-and-click adventure game, you get a little sword fighting/blocking action which is great in my opinion.*Music! Awesome feel.*Art style is very unique and beautiful.Cons:*Not much replay value, but for a low price that's not much of an issue for some people.9/10

content:
Posted: January 18, 2014
												Sword & Sworcery's atmosphere is heavily built on the use of sound and music. It uses it to create tension during combat as well as a sense of calm and mystery during the more exploratory parts of the game.The story is structured from short sentences describing your surroundings, the thoughts of various characters, and the presence of reoccuring characters. Most of the time it builds a light mythology for itself, though some of the phrasing used is designed to replicate a more modern speech pattern, a sort of meta-narrative.Difficulty is created by reducing the player's health as they progress, and while this may sound trivial, it is cleverly tied into the story and allows for simple combat that doesn't need to throw additional mechanics at the player.

content:
Posted: February 13, 2016
												This game is a MASTER PIECE that IS NOT FOR EVERY PLAYER.This game is neither a point and click adventure nor a rogue-like nor RPG. It is most a GENRE BY ITSELF, a masterpiece as I have said. Graphics and music are georgous, but its own style goes from the menuscreen to the interface of the game, even to its internal logic, which is not designed to be fully understood. This is not a game for a harcore gameplay, you are supposed to guess what to do next by observing with your five senses inside the game, and out of the game too, because the time at you play it influences in the developing of the game. You are understanding the game, its logic and its own rythm as you play it, so judging it just at the begining is not to judge the game, but reject its potential.

content:
Posted: December 27, 2013
! 7/10The one problem with this game is its designed for tablet or touch surface in particular. This can lead to an epic battle digressing to a show down with your mouse and the two button battle mode instead of the in-game enemy.Outside of this issue the aesthetic balance between the game's graphics and sound is amazing. The sound pairs with the actions you preform in the game enviroment so readily that you experience a whole new dynamic to the gameplay rarely felt in games; where sound becomes as stirring an emotional influence as the visuals. Many of the scenes are so well crafted that the sound effects of enemies, or even your own actions, blend seamlessly into the music giving the impression of perfect symmetry between player and game as even your own decisions occur seemingly in perfectly harmony with the soundscape. It has been a long time since a game enviroment has engrossed me to the extent that video games did in my early childhood taking me on epic adventures and journeys. Play Sword and Sworcery for the good laughs from the offbeat humor and the musical crescendo of nostalgia that is its classic story line.

												A bearded man in a vest adorned with chinese symbols taps out "Stairway to Heaven" on a xylophone, eyes glazed over, mouthing the lyrics to "Sister Ray".A werewolf sits amidst the burned down remains of a Starbucks. clutching a plum and shedding a single tear. number of helpful: 5 of 12 people (42%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 24, 2015
												Sword & Sworcery features a female warrior on a quest to reunite triangles lost in a mysterious fantasy realm located somewhere between dream and reality. The intriguing story is divided into three increasingly long sessions, each briefly presented by monologue from The Archetype, with a shorter final one acting as a sort of conclusion.Very appealing and well executed pixel art embodies artistic simplicity met with astounding precision and remarkable sensitivity. Simple but fluid animations infused into every corner of the world, along with subtle color shifts that gracefully enhance the liveliness of the scenes, create a mesmerizing environment unlike any other.A solid soundtrack suits the mood perfectly, composed mostly of rock-tinged retro ambient ballads, properly extravagant mood trips, doom and gloom, and a wealth of high quality atmospheric sounds.Dishearteningly and despite all the game does exceptionally well, there is too much to loathe about everything done wrong, or too peculiar to be enjoyable. Every time it surprised me with an awesome moment, of which there are a good few, it had to immediately remind me of its many glaringly frustrating elements.Sword & Sworcery's totally awkward controls, obviously initially created for touch devices, do not play well in a mouse configuration, despite efforts made to ease the transition. Almost every design decision taken by the developer seems counter intuitive or ergonomically inefficient. Thankfully simple hints pop up from time to time to explain the more cryptic expectations.Dreadful combat sequences require learning unavoidable patterns and hitting one of two buttons at the right moment, often with no clear consequence until repeated exposure. Later combat sequences can only be described as cheap rhythm games akin to playing ping pong. And waiting. Battles are exceptionally long for surprisingly so little action, as most of the time is spent waiting for a cue. Fights are so unequivocally counter-intuitive that an explanation comes after each failed attempt in the game's Megatome, a sort of encyclopedia chronicling important characters' personal thoughts.The same boring and uneventful fights keep re-happening fairly frequently, without actual rewards, presumably to artificially extend playing time.There are some funny and/or clever bits of dialogues and descriptions, though it eventually becomes banal to read blurbs drenched in juvenile hipster crass hidden among rare gems. Despite the intriguing setting and the very charming characters, the whole affair reads like an aspiring author's collection of best attempts at mystic alliterations and esoteric one-liners.Most Sworcery puzzles mainly consist in (optionally) ingesting magic mushrooms to see specific parts of the environment lit up, then figuring out in which pre-determined order the game expects you to click to release sylvan sprites. I found no logic to these segments most of the time, so it turned out to be tedious guesswork for the more obtuse ones and deceivingly simple otherwise.Parts of the game accurately synchronize with the actual moon's phases, marking one of the game's most unique and truly original ideas. Fortunately, the developers realized that being able to play entire sections of their game only once a month at full and new moons was a spectacularly bad proposition, and they built a way to temporarily alter the phases of the moon directly in the game, essentially circumventing the entire feature's purpose and value.A few other minor flaws and annoyances include the main character constantly referring to herself in the second person, completely useless Twitter integration on every single line, slow character movement, and too often self-referential for its own benefit.This game offers a beautiful world in which I would love to get lost for hours, if only it offered anything worthwhile to do. As it stands, its long list of frustrating elements far outweigh everything else I so desperately loved.

content:
Posted: June 26, 2015
												Wait, let me explain.SB:S&S EP should not be considered a video game in the traditional sense.  It is an interactive multimedia art experience.  Coming into it with that attitude will provide the right frame of mind to potentially enjoy it.  All art is subjective.As a game it isn't very interesting.  The world to be explored is composed of a handful of set scenes.  Combat is both simple and repetitive.  Most of the puzzles are simple if you are keeping up with the dialog.  You will not be challenged here.  There is a very strong 'hipster' vibe throughout.  If that's what you are into, huzzah, but for me it was grating.

number of helpful: 1 of 4 people (25%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 19, 2015
												A point and click game designed for iphone users with plenty of social media intergration, chatspeak ingame dialog, and confusing puzzles which they intended for the user to repeatedly come back to at different times to see if the solution presents itself. As a PC user, this is less than thrilling or entertaining. Sure it's got good music and they definitely have an interesting art style (which I don't like but I'll give credit for the attempt) but there's little else going for it. The story unfolds slowly, and it wasn't enough to keep me paying attention. Dialog and descriptions are always either really weird and nonsensical or written as if you got a text message from someone else on an iphone, which strikes me as really lame. As you scroll sideways occasionally you'll get in a fight or a puzzle. Fights are a mess which probably didn't need to even be in this puzzle game, but whatever. Puzzles sometimes require different touches or gestures which would seem natural to an iphone gamer, but not to a PC user. In addition the puzzles often give no clues or really vague clues as to their solution. Puzzles are really obtuse. In fact, as I hinted earlier, the game is connected with your clock and calendar, and certain puzzles can more or less easily-or sometimes not at all- be solved at specific times of day or phases of the moon. Again, this would be more interesting if I was on a phone playing 15 minutes at a time, a couple times a day.I dunno, some reviewers say it's a masterpiece, but the only masterful part about it is the music. Maybe I'm wrong, but even if a game is boring or frustrating, isn't the dialog and story supposed to keep me interested to push through? Well, didn't happen here.

content:
Posted: July 18, 2015
												S:S&S is a game that tries too hard.Its visual and audio style are both incredible, and the game is a joy to experience, but it quickly goes downhill once you start trying to actually do something.The controls are the first thing that hits you. It becomes immediately apparent that this is an iPad game. 'Replacing touch with a mouse is clumy, but I can deal with that,' you say. And so you deal with it. The controls don't seem to get more intuitive, but at least they're workable.Then you get to a girl named Girl, and that seems quirky. And this quirkiness stays pretty consistent, which means it gets a little annoying. There's a g-man that says a bunch of big words that essentially mean nothing, a woodman that states the obvious, and a dog that barks. Whatever, you've seen iffy writing before, and you continue.But then you realize that you're incredibly slow. Annoyingly so. Most of the game is spent waiting for your character to slowly meander across the beautiful pixel landscape. You can only explore an area the first time through, but this game will keep sending you back and forth through it. So you deal with it.This slowness carries through to your interactions with things. Everything needs to be clicked and held, or maybe rubbed for a while. Or strummed or touched just right, or poked a few times.Which brings us to the puzzles. If you can call them that. You click and hold on a thing (for a while,) then you have to interact with... something. Sometimes that something glows, sometimes it doesn't. Sometimes you need to slowly walk over to a mushroom and eat that first before you can see the thing you have to do something to. And once you figure out what you're interacting with, and how to interact with it, you have to divine what ORDER to interact with those things. I could find no rhyme, reason, or explanation to how this worked. It was pretty much just random clicking that eventually got me through.'But this game is rated Mostly Positive in user reviews!' you say. And yes, it is, so you keep going, thinking that there's gotta be something incredibly redeeming about this game.Perhaps this is so highly rated because it wallows in how artsy it is. Everything about this game is artsy. Yes, it's pretty. Yes, it sounds good. Yes, it's pretentious. But that doesn't make it good. Anyway, you think this, and continue on to...The first boss. Now, combat up to this point has been pretty simple. There's been a wolf that you block attacks from, and it seems like you can't hit it, though it's never explained why not; and there was a statue or something that you blocked and then hit while it was stunned. That was actually pretty okay. But the boss? Oh no, it doesn't follow the few combat rules laid out up to this point.So far, the player has been shown that you are capable of blocking god damn anything with your shield. So the boss betrays your trust with an unblockable attack. You fumble your way to finding the solution to this little problem and make it to the next step. Now the boss triggers an audio cue, at which point you tap the block button and dodge to the side. THIS IS NOT INDICATED OR USED UP TO THIS POINT. Until you dodge, you don't even know that dodging is a mechanic. This is terrible design.Zelda gets blasted for overusing the new toy and throwing it away at the end of a dungeon. But do you know why they do that? The entire dungeon is spent training the player how to use said toy before offering a final test of the player's skill in the form of the boss fight. S:S&S throws this entire concept to the wind and throws random crap at you and laughs when you don't pick it up immediately.I think the boss is supposed to be beaten through trial and error, but 'trial and error' and 'figue out the new mechanic on the spot' are not the same thing. And since everything takes so damn long (the boss's first attack is over a minute after you triger it, every time,) it's really hard to keep pushing yourself through this encounter.I certainly didn't.And that is why I do not recommend this game. Maybe get the soundtrack and poke a Let's Play or something, because it's really pretty and sounds great.

content:
Posted: July 23, 2016
												Do not buy this game. The gameplay is extremely limited - click to move; click to interact with object; click to send a tweet about object.The environment is bland and uninteresting; with the artstyle looking vague and on the wrong side of "indie" (read: disgusting).The main selling point of this game seems to be the OST, given the name of this game (Sword and Sworcery EP), but the soundtrack is just as uninspired as the rest of the game; it's generic and not at all memorable. Even the movement controls in this game are terrible. Want to move to an object? Double click on it. OOPS! Looks like nyour reading a description of the object isntead of going over to it. And why are you giving me the option to send a tweet about literally every single interaction I am having in this game? People arent going to care! In-fact, it'll probably annoy them.The characters as just as shallow as this game is ugly. I had no idea that the player character is supposed to be a woman. Yep. That scrambled, elongated mess of pixels is supposed to be a woman.The writing trys to be funny and meta, but comes across as. again, uninspired and snarky. There seems to be no effort to try to make the player feel as if they are imersed within this fantastical world. Instead, it feels like a powerpoint presentation of screens that the character shambles through for no reason whatsoever. There is no goal presented to you at the start of the game, and no real stakes whatsoever.The "combat" is nothing more than a quicktime event, and when being "chased" by a baddy, all you need to do to outrun them is click on the exit.Simply put, this game is a bland, boring, stakless "adventure" with no real purpose. Alomst every single element in this game is underwhelming to say the least.Please do not purchase this game.

content:
Posted: November 19, 2014
												Sword & Sworcery is a short adventure game. It introduces a minimalistic and novel way to bring adventure games to touchscreen devices, but left me with the feeling that a pc game can be so much more. In adventures I live for atmosphere. While Sword & Sworcery's art and music do that perfectly (I really recommend the soundtrack), the narrative harshly drops the built up immersion in favor of ironically juxtaposing prose with blasé pop chatter. After finishing the game, I still don't have an understanding of my character's motives beyond that of any Mario game, and found no memorable companions along the way.

Posted: June 10, 2014
												Perhaps I'm not the best to judge this game considering I have 2 hours logged in it. But that's the thing; In the two hours I've been playing the game, nothing has happened! I'll concede that the art is good, and the music is fantastic, but if I wanted to sit there and listen to music, I'd be doing that instead of trying to play a game.The game tries to be atmospheric, but all this does is set a pace that's way too slow. After a while, I hadn't really DONE anything. I had gone where the little arrows told me to go, and done what the little text boxes told me to do, but that's about it. I want to like this game, and I want to see the poetry in it, but no poem I've ever read requires me to sit through two hours of holding down a mouse and watching a pixellated character walk across a screen just to get to the good bit, wherever it may be.If you're into atmosphere, or you want to stare at pretty pixels while relaxing background music plays, buy this game. If you want to play a videogame, don't.

content:
Posted: December 29, 2014
												I really wanted to like this game. I love the rest of capy's games, but this one I couldn't get into. The art style and music is great. It is in the gameplay where this game falls short. Very easy and uninspired gameplay. It feels like a stripped down version of rpg combat. The game has you progress by walking SLOWLY between areas solving the same tedious puzzles over and over again, just to obtain these 3 triangles called trigon pieces. The overall game was not very fun, from slow walk speed, to tedious puzzles, a predictable story, to banal combat. The moment when I stopped was after obtaining the 2nd trigon piece and having the game say that in order to obtain the last piece I had to wait real world days for the next full moon. You could always change your clock but that would prevent you from getting 100%. Overall a beautiful looking yet disappointing game that is more fun to look at than to play.

number of helpful: 3 of 9 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 22, 2016
												A very mixed bag. Nice music, very nice sounds, I personally like the pixel asthetic, and in essence the game is an adequate but simple puzzle/adventure with a smidgen of quicktime-like action sequence. However, the writing is completely off in tone--super casual, very modern, laden with adolescent slang, and what little voice acting there is has the same issue. It might be going for a Katamari Damacy feel, but it comes across as disrespectful toward the material, and toward the player. Overall, cutesy. Cool if you're into that. Worth a couple of bucks.Then there's the marketing and hype. It's an obvious indie-scene darling, thanking Brandon Boyer, former Chairman of the IGF. But then it also has an award from the IGF and the GDC? Wins or is nominated Best Game by almost 2 dozen gaming publications, including IGN, Kotaku, Gamasutra, 1up, Gamesradar, PCMag, Venturebeat, Wired, Destructoid, on and on? One of Time Magazine's Video Games of the Year sitting beside Portal 2, Skyrim, Minecraft, and Dark Souls? I don't know who is in Capybara Games, but the wiki says it's a collection of IGDA members. So the same people making the games are the ones giving it awards. Am I supposed to believe it's being done on merit?This strains credulity well beyond reason. Keep in mind this is one indie game released the same year as Bastion, Terraria, and Binding of Isaac.  This reeks of having schmoozed its way to the top. In a fair world, I'd recommend this game and suggest buying it for $5 or less. But in the face of such ridiculous, hyperbolic, and inescapable praise, no. I cannot add a recommendation to such a sea of duplicity.

content:
Posted: January 16, 2015
												Sometimes it pays to be pretty. Especially if your personality is akin to that of a differently-abled llama.The pixel art is great, no doubt. However the scenery soon becomes repetitive and the initial charm of the landscapes diminishes. The clunky, unintuitive contols frustrate often. In particular, a chase scene quickly goes from tense and urgent to mouse-throwingly-irritating. As you try to escape, your mouse clicks "grab" the screen, dragging the scene in the opposite direction of the one in which you were attempting to move. Throw in the painfully glacial pace of your protagonist and navigating this lovely low-res world becomes a chore. Essentially the gameplay itself is pinned upon almost a singular mechanic, initiating "scorcery mode" and activating the environmental surroundings through mouse clicks in a specific order to release Forest Sprites. It's simplistic at its core, but often obtuse. You may however consume mushrooms to highlight these specific points of interaction, but maybe 'shrooms is how we've ended up here in the first place.  For all the emphasis on the soundtrack or the "EP", the tunes here are generally uninspiring, background ambience. A grating bell-dong accompanies every scroll of on-screen text that feels quite unnecessary. Although, the grunts and cries of your protaganist during battle sound fierce and have a Link-like charm. There's also a rambling, awkward monologue from a character that was somewhat amusing.The attempted casual, modern style of the text is an innovative idea, but feels forced. The word "super" is repeatedly thrown in front of adjectives, endevouring to be current.In spite of all this, I found the choice of a female lead character to be a commendable one. It's just a shame she doesn't have more to do.The parting announcement S:SS leaves you with- "Your woeful errand is at an end." Indeed... Indeed it is.Super disappointing.

content:
Posted: January 27, 2014
												When I first played the game, I thought the atmosphere and the art style was great. Although that was the only thing that this game really had to offer. In terms of gameplay, Sword & Sworcery had awkward point-and-click mechanics that would make walking from one side to another a chore especially since you have to walk through the same pathways over and over. The puzzles were too easy and combat was lackluster and unchallenging, making it annoying and pointless to fight that shadow guy everytime you have to walk through the same pathway a millionth time. The writing was also irritating as it tends to make unnecessary self-commentary everytime something happens that takes away any meaning to the story in a shallow attempt to be funny. And let's not forget that annoying voice acting of Logfella when he tries to make awkward conversations with you; it's unfunny and out of character (no attempt to sound like an old woodsman and instead sounds like an awkward teenager) which loses any immersion to the game. Overall I liked the style of the game but gameplay mechanics and story were not good. Not worth the 2 dollars I spent on this game.

content:
Posted: February 14, 2015
												I have to say, I do like to play the 'experimental' games as they are usually interesting concepts and make a change from the usual run of the mill FPS I usualy play. Having said that, I didn't especially enjoy this. It's decent enough, and certainly intriguing. I personally just found the control system somewhat cumbersome, and had a really hard time figuring ut what the heck i was meant to be doing most of the time. I don't mind games that leave you to figure stuff out on your own, but most of the time, I just ended up wandering about doing random things until something happened to progress, more by good luck than logically figured out.  Having said that, the good soundtrack and retro style graphics did apeal and kind of added to the otherworldly-ness (not sure if that's a word!) of the atmosphere. There wasn't anything particularly terrible about this game, but nothing particularly stood out about this, aside from the soundtrack. And, I confess, the link into the social media kind of felt more gimmicky than innovative.  would I recommend it? In all honesty, probably not. There are plenty of 'experimental' games out there which feel much more accessible than this, and manage to combine innnovative ideas and gameplay (Dear Esther, for example, or Shelter even are two that spring to mind). Full marks for effort, but a bit too inaccessible for me.

												Superbrothers: Sword & Sworcery EP was an interesting game. ...But not interesting enough.And what I mean by that is through my complete playthrough of the game, the game felt like it was trying to convey a bigger thought. A bigger picture and a larger frame of imagination.What bothers me is the game conveys these thoughts but then suddenly ends when it felt like it needed to start show casing it's cloud of information and thoughts of enlightenment.It was a pretty impressionable lacking feeling.The world SB:S&S takes place in was one that felt like it had a substantial amount of lore and background, but you were just a watcher who commands a Scythian to complete a quest they called "A Woeful Errand" It felt like that besides the errand, the world it takes place in isn't extremely meaningful to you as you're there to guide the Scythian to complete her mission. So most lore can easily be ignored or you can make the Scythian get a little bit of background information from reading her thoughts on the world around her and talking to other people. I appreciate that is was natural and people weren't just flushing the worlds background out of them into you.The game has an interesting way of connecting you to the characters involved in the game. Your character shortly after starting her errand aquires a book dubbed "The Megatome"The Megatome allows you to see how many days until the next real life black moon or full moon. It also allows you to read the minds of others and establishes an interesting connection to people around you. Mind you, this function isn't gimmicky and isn't overdone. It's pretty simple but interesting.This game is a point and click adventure without a doubt. It was released first on the IOS and then for PC. During my playthrough, i'd say it's a little better suited for the IOS. But it works pretty darn well on the PC too, so it is a pretty good port nonetheless.The playing world is pretty narrow in-movement, but as far as what you need to do and exploring goes. The game respects your thoughts on where to go and what you should do. There is times where I got lost or tried to solve a puzzle in a area where there was no puzzle to be solved (by using the song of sworcery). But ultimately after maybe ten minutes at worst, i'd figure out where I needed to be and then they game kept moving.I appreciate that and the time loss isn't that bad, the only thing that will probably bother you about that is when you gotta hike all the way to where you need to be. The Scythians pacing can be a bit tiresome and annoying sometimes.The art style of the game is pretty great. Sometimes I feel like it wasn't tied too strongly to the story, so sometimes the art styles impact fell kind of short when the story was uprising towards it approach to its climax.Though at-times the art and the colors and sounds mixed-in with what was happening helped achieve a state of artistic enlightenment and a different kind of view on things. ...Also getting high on the occassional in-game mushroom helped that out a bit sometimes.Unfortunately, the same can be equally be said about the music. The music was perfect in areas and it carried emotions out of me. Feelings of intensity, feelings of whimsical peaceful happiness and others.But unfortunately as I said, there was times where the music felt really out-of-place or it was hard to understand what the music meant in-conjunction to the story or what was going on.Though that aside, the connections I grew with side characters and main characters was very nice. My personal favorite being the Grizzled Boor. I like how in the game the story isn't painfully linear. You actually may never even see the grizzled boor until the ending or there's other parts in the progression of the story where you may think that was just the story running its course. But not so, this helps build a level of replayability in the game. Though i'd say probably one or two playthroughs after the first, and you'll never play this game again most likely.The combat system is pretty basic and unimportant, which is good since it's not really a meaningful compenent of the game in the first place. Though there was a time where a battle felt really tense unexpected and there was a time where I had to fight someone and I didn't want to hurt them in the first place.Combat is pretty sparse, and usually pops-up in places when you've gotten kind of sick of the scythians mundane pacing through the world.That all aside, the game is a experience and a expression. They said it themselves that this game is an experiment (a social one (it encourages you to tweet things about the game)). I wouldn't really agree that it was a successful one or that they could get much data from their experiment, but it was still an okay test in my opinion. Though they needed to provoke more thought and stimulation of emotions in the game.Also they not only called it a social experiment, but also a sound experiment. Shamefully that lacked at a good amount of points too (as explained earlier) and after the 3rd chapter, you'd consider the sound experiment something of a joke. It had its time when it was woven very eloquently, but it wasn't consistently often and done very well.Perhaps the most touching parts of the sound experiment was when I was awakening Sylvian Sprites and when I sent them to the heavens above you would hear a happy child giggling and the sky would lighten for a second. I honestly cherished those moments when I was awakening the spirits and the peaceful tranquil sounds they made as you tapped them touched my soul a little bit.So ultimately, we arrive at the point. "Should you get this game?", and I say maybe.Through the games pieces of lacking material and parts of confusion and changing wavelengthts of script quality.There's parts and pieces of this game that are actually good, are things that need to be presented to the player.You won't get much out of it if you don't think a little bit about some of the things in this game for a short bit after or even during the game.I'd recommend getting it on a picecut like I did though.

content:
Posted: March 14, 2014
												Superbrothers is to gaming what Adventure Time is to TV: something I just don’t get. Or maybe something you can only "get" if you're high.Controls are bad, graphics are junk, music is forgettable, story is…well, I’m not sure there is a story aside from references to other games like Zelda. I thought this would be an amusing diversion for an evening but instead it put me to sleep. Literally. I struggled to finish the first part because I kept dozing off. Shocked at how many people are praising the visuals. It’s nothing but blocky pixels everywhere, allegedly arranged in “poetic” fashion. Whatever.Superbrothers is sort of like Another World: there are action-type areas with puzzles mixed in. Except Another World is much better in every way, even the graphics, so you might as well play that instead. In fact, do anything else instead. If you have no other video game to play, read a book, surf the internet, eat a sandwich, exercise, anything. Your time will be better spent.

number of helpful: 0 of 3 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 1, 2013
												Saw a review on this once that called it hipster garbage. Actually pretty accurate. Even as a person who generally enjoys good indies and isn't only attached to AAA's, I have to admit that the game has an indie-hipster feel that's a little too overpowering, and gameplay is meh. It's very clearly intended for touchscreen, which is annoying, the puzzles aren't clever buy simply obtuse, and the game beckons at every corner for you to tweet about its nonsense like "Trigonal Trifectas", which is clearly simply a clever homage to Zelda and definitely not a ripoff.This isn't to say that the game is worthless at all. A couple of things redeem it somewhat- 1, the nice visuals, which put the low bit count style to great use with nice lighting and colors, and 2, the music, which is equally atmospheric and inviting. I certainly wouldn't recommend paying full price for it, but if you pick it up from a bundle or for a dollar or two you might as well try it out, even if it's not that great it's still certainly no disaster.

												What's the only thing more horrible than a game having obnoxious QTEs slowing you down?I'll tell you: It's having a d0uchebag-level pretentious game completely halting your progress because of your computer's ACTUAL TIME AND DATE settings.I swear on my Gaben altar, I am not making this up:Lo and behold, this game demands you play it according to the £uckin' REAL WORLD MOON CYCLES to progress. Unless you got some key, which is only available if it is not a full or dark moon in REAL LIFE, which it of course wasn't the day I played it. Hence locking you out of getting the key and being able to alter the games moon phases with the cave that this key grants access to.I was ready to recommend this because of decent pixel artwork, nice music and all-around greatness, but when the games' messing with real world MOON CYCLES stops you from playing, well, that's just a boatload of steaming hipster sh|te that no one in their right mind would succumb themselves to.Into the garbage bin you go, you annoying filth of bits and bytes.
