number of helpful: 7 of 30 people (23%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 7, 2016
												Remember the times when you had to explore the land, uncovering secrets?  How you had to block enemy projectiles and avoid sword swings?  Timing your counterattacks?  Well, let's just♥♥♥♥♥♥all over this concept, and casualize it for the dumbed down audience of Tumblr and company (you can even link it to your Twitter, to annoy your audience with quotes of the game).The game is unbearably slow, and there's only but straight paths, making navigation a huge chore, only gets even worse when the creepto dude shows his face all the damn time.  It holds you by your hand, with instructions telling you what to do, and the combat is so simple it only requires an ounce of common sense.  The puzzles are nonsensical, like having to hold onto various objects, such as sheeps, in some order I can't grasp at all, wasting my time further, and rubbing the rainbows as the game tells you to, what?  There's also that thing about having to wait for two moon cycles in real life to get Trifor- I mean Trigon pieces; that's the stuff for side missions, not for progression.  There is the Moon Cave, but the game solely advertise waiting a month for the moon to fully shine, which is dumb.  (But... but it's art!!!)  Yeah, your usual artsy trash that us "plebians" can't comprehend.There are times that the game even tricks me into wasting my time; I had to first set the full moon from the Moon Cave, deep in the freaking long forest, go back to the Logfella's cabin to go to the Dream, to do all my errands with the ghost kids.  Afterwards, I had to find the "miracle", but the dog hurried me to go back to the cabin, so I did, but then the Logfella woke me up, and the moon is now at a crescent, meaning I had to do the WHOLE TRIP again!  That's not fun, it's ♥♥♥♥ing stupid.Why are you even doing all this, what such inspired tale has you travel these lands?  Well it's really just jack all, you simply go collect the 3 legendary triangles to defeat the evil, all while speaking to characters that have as much depth as the underside of my fingernail.  It's the same kind of story that video games have been built upon for years, that whiny critics complain about constantly, and yet this is just riveting of creativity because it has some bullcrap, ambiguous elements that the developpers just didn't bother elaborating on, and uses some coquettish way of speaking that may make you feel bad if you try to play the game.Oh yeah, and make it obvious I could've not killed the bear thing or whatever, which I did thought of, but now it just calls me some sociopath because its mechanics were too trash, failing to point out I could've pulled away the sword, I couldn't even walk away!  Heck, when I slained it after a minute of trying to get out, wasn't it also me just putting it out of its misery, of its slit throat?  If you're going to shove me that kind of morality crap, make it work right for crying out loud.Graphics-wise, well, it's at least better than Greenlit games, but really, no matter how good it may be, it will not save anything, it'd be like putting the artists of the Fantasy Zone series behind the next Barbie movie, it'd be such a waste.  And even then, this game has no depth in its design, I think the pixel art is just a lazy way to not bother giving it a proper art style like many other 8-or-so-bit-like indie games, and the environments aren't so full of details and imagination that you'd try to imagine what might be going on in the distance, and aren't just fun to look at.  This game has no character, there's no magic, it's only pretending to have a soul by its ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t storytelling that doesn't always make reasonable sense.Why am I so offended by it anyway?  Not only because it has no worth, but people want to shove this crappy concept of storytelling down our throats, much like Thirty Flights of Loving, they say that the Scythian is one of the best woman in gaming despite having no faults, no motives for her actions, just an hollow shell, and when it tries to be artsy or showing morals like the aforementionned bear, it fails miserably.  Plus, apparently having no gameplay whatsoever is excusable due to its presentation, no matter how crap the story and art style are.Our game design principles, that we have been refining for 30+ years, have stepped to such low levels ever since we thought that making you solely feel emotions is a much more fulfilling experience than the sense of accomplishment of defeating the final boss after a 20+ hour long endeavor.  Not to say we always need a happy ending, nor does it have to be platformers or shoot 'em ups, but there has to be something we must get out of the experience, and games should have a perfect balance of gameplay and presentation that make each of them stand out.  This game here hasn't delivered anything, yet it's one of the best game of all time, go ♥♥♥♥ yourself.I utterly hate these games that focus more on story and "art", as the developpers have no idea on having any redeeming gameplay, and goes totally against my principles of game design.You want a game?  Play some Zelda, which is actually what this game was "inspired" by.  Even if I'm not a big fan of that series, it's miles better than this piece of dung, as it requires some actual skills, you could find neat secrets, and more importantly, has gameplay.  And since we talked about art, how about Donkey Kong Country 2?  That game is still gorgeous even to this day, having a sweet, emotional atmosphere, all while having excellent gameplay still unparalleled, and remains one of my favorite games, heck Diddy's character development in the manual has much more wits than the Scythian's lame attempt at it.  I also thought that Athena on NES just didn't worked on every fronts, but I've actually started seeing it in a more positive light, realizing that it at least didn't pretented to be something else, which I think would be the most toxic way of thinking.Sword & Sworcery, on the other hand, is absolute trash, just a dumb, glorified book.  It is, without a doubt, the worst game I've ever played.

Posted: June 2, 2013
												First thing's first. See that title? Sword & Sworcery is an EP, not a game proper. It is music foremost and a storytelling experience second.Despite what you may think and hear, this game is far from pretentious, and one of few examples where people will point to when they say that games can be art. Here is one so accutely self-aware that it nearly transcends it.At its base, Sword & Sworcery is a wacky adventure tied onto a pretty nifty soundtrack. It is an experiment in modern storytelling and game design. A fruitful experiment, infusing music with puzzles and battles and decidedly not vice versa. The visuals, as you can already tell, are beyond stunning.S&S is a game that tells its story almost in a sarcastic, tongue-in-cheek manner. At risk small of ruining the surprise, I will say this: it is exactly this silliness that both allows you to come even close to taking it seriously, and the cleverness that makes you appreciate it all the more.If the plot were presented in a serious manner, few would take it seriously and it would just seem as pretentious and obfuscated as Braid. It is the humour and quirkiness of the title that makes the story penetrable at all. Despite the jests, the story is even more compelling if you take it as being honest.Now here's the sad bits: this is not meant for the PC at all. Find yourself a touch screen copy of this game. It is not meant to be completed in one or two sittings. You are meant to pace yourself and take it in chunks, and you'll be more likely to finish the game that way.Missing the ending is something you do not want to do. That is when everything sinks in.

Posted: August 21, 2012
												I got really attracted to this game at first because of its art. Now it completely took me over with its original music and sounds -- not to mention its quirky style when it comes to text and words in the game. Posted: December 1, 2012
												This game is realy funky.  I mean, on a completely superfluous level, it's gorgeous.  The sprite art and scenery is so simple but so decorative and detailed.  It's an amazing look.  And Jim Guthrie's music is just the best part about the whole game.  I've never fallen in love with a game's music faster than I have with Superbrothers.The gameplay is hit and miss for me.  I liked the exploration aspect, but the puzzles are usually far from tricky and the combat is clearly made for touch-screen devices like Android of iOS.  The three Trigon "boss fights" are also all basically the same, and considering those are some of the only enemies you encounter in the game, it would have been nice to see some creativity.  That being said, I would imagine they wanted as little combat as possible, so maybe that's why?  I dunno.As I mentioned, the exploration is pretty awesome.  You get dragged into the atmosphere so quickly because of the beautiful visuals and music.  And there are so many things you interact with and the Megatome's constant "thought journal" is just brilliant.  The "Lunar Cycle" system is also interesting for sure, and I kind of like how the entire game is kind of focused more on the "spiritual experience" it's trying to offer you.  It's unorthodox but very welcomed.The characters are all very fleshed out, and the narrator herself is charming and witty.  You really feel for her by the end of the journey because...well, I can't spoil but it 's some pretty heavy stuff.  The story isn't too explicit, but unlike titles like Limbo which left me wanting a lot more, Superbrothers just barely manages to quench the thirst.  I don't need to know more...I can simple assume and I'm totally fine with that.Honestly, I'd recommend Superbrothers if you got it in the Humble Bundle or if you can just grab it for cheap.  You can beat it in four or five hours or so, but you'll probably go back and play it a few times just because it's actually impossible to see everything in the first playthrough.  The music and visuals are worth the purchase on their own, so check this out if you want something different but very, very interesting.

												This game is beautifully different. It echoes such favorites as Zelda, but goes far beyond paying tribute. Posted: May 3, 2014
												Wow... I owned this game for a long time before playing it. I had no idea what I was missing out on. Great retro adventure game, with an interesting story that isn't shoved down the players throat. The player is thrown into a world s/he knows nothing about, in a game where the mechanics are not explained by some boring tutorial or lame on-screen directions. Instead, the game cleverly introduces concept little by little, nudging the player to understand. Doing all of this, without being frustrating or annoying, rather keeping the player intrigued to know more.  Also great for casuals as it is divided up into sections that seem to take 30-45 minutes. GREAT GAME, HIGHLY RECOMMENDED!

Posted: May 6, 2014
												Superbrothers: Sword & Sworcery EP is one of the best games I have played this year. It's blend of lush, beautiful pixel art, engrossing sound effects and score, and intuitve gameplay sets the bar for indie games several pegs higher.Although the gameplay mechanics are designed for touch-enabled devices, I had no issues using a mouse to click, drag, and strum my way though game. The combat system was probably easier on touch, but I only encountered a few mis-clicks in my five-and-a-half hour playthrough.I believe it would be very easy for someone to beat this game for the first time in four hours, but I managed to get turned around a few times, especially in Session 3. The characters generally guide you along well enough to your next goal, though the hints can be quite cryptic at times. When I did finally find my way again, it was only then that I realized the true meaning.At its core, the indiekid/hipster vibe of this game will either make or break the experience for you. The vocal tracks, few and far between, remind me of more of a spaced-out Bill and Ted than one would expect from a game, and both the developers and sound/music guy Jim Guthrie managed to have cameos. I found these traits endearing, the final polish on an already unblemished game. If you find yourself allergic to alliteration (or pretentiousness), then you might have a hard time with this one.

4 out of 5

Posted: January 23, 2014
												More than a review, I just want to make a comment about this game. I have heard a lot of people (including critics) speak very positively about Superbrothers, but to be completely honest I just don't get it. Sure, the music is really good and it does an amazing job making you feel invested in the world. And definitely, the visual art is certainly very different from everything else out there. But I just don't think that this game is fun. I understand battles are secondary to what the game truly is, but they just felt very boring, since they just play out like quick-time events except with a mouse. Not to mention that the the whole sworcery sections were just clicks here and there, somewhat confusing and unappealing. I just did not find the puzzles as interesting as some people have said they were. All in all, Superbrothers feels like an unbalanced game. Stay for the ambient and music if you want to, cause there isn't that much else. There are better indie games out there.

Posted: January 24, 2014
												Awful waste of a few pounds. Such a high metacritic score, so surely worth a bash, right? No. First I hated that it wanted me to sign into twitter all the time so it could advertise itself on my feed. Next, the story could possibly have been good, but you'd never know it from the awful 'ironic hipster' style of narration. It's as though a twelve year old stoner was given the job of writing the written cues. Whilst there's good music and a nice graphic style, the gameplay consists of walking around an incredibly repetative environment and clicking on every point, hoping to achieve something or figure out what the next step is by chance. Poor effort in making gameplay comparable to an actually playable game. I repeat; terrible 'game'. I'd reconsider the gaming credentials of anyone who considers this passable as a recommendation.

Posted: August 26, 2014
												Music: The soundtrack. The soundtrack the soundtrack the soundtrack. Soundtrack? The. Soundtrack.Sound Effects: I don't think I have ever commented on sound effects. I mean, voice acting, sure, but that to me is its own category. I also want to cater my chatter to the games themselves since oftentimes something stands out on its own and needs to be talked about. That said, the sound effects are crisp, elegant, real, magical. I think crisp is a delicious word; it makes me happy. Crisp. That was the first thing I thought of when I watched the Steam Release video. It carries throughout the game. Moments where there is little music are made vibrant by the sound effects. Not an "oh I hear birds, how realistic" or "oh the people in the distant market, I can hear them!" vibrancy. It goes deeper into an almost trance inducing simplistic beauty. It dances in your mind. It dances with your mind.Story: Simple. At least to me it wasn't terribly deep, but I admit that I didn't spend an enormous amount of time in the game. The writing is superb though. I was pulled into the mystery of the game mostly becasue I didn't feel I had to be playing the game to be a part of it. The story became part of my own. The woeful errand is mine.Gameplay (A): The controls and actual gameplay are brutally straightforward and it works. I felt good about accomplishing things but it was more of an "Ah-ha! Got it!" feeling than an "I did it! I can't believe it! YEEEEAAAAHHHH!" feeling. That said, the last part of the game gives you the latter feeling.Gameplay (B): The way it incorporates into life would have been more engaging if I used twitter. Still, this game got me to actually make a twitter account, so that was something. I haven't used twitter since, so...yeah. Anywho, even despite that element being wasted on this guy I found the way this ties into the real world to be the best thing ever. I am sure some people will think it is lame, but I loved it. I don't want to ruin it, you can always look it up if you want, but it is astronomy related. Nothing complex. Nothing you can't google your way into knowing. But I was enraptured.Graphics: Obviously not for everyone. I loved them. It manages to be pixel art while also being art. Not all pixel art games are terribly pretty, but this one is. Nostalgia doesn't even have much to do with it. It is an art style and I love what they have done with it.Overall: I bought it, obviously. I watched the release trailer and knew I had to. I am recommending it. I bought the soundtrack. I fell in love with the mystery and ambiance of this game. You could read a hundred reviews that say this is amazing and you may think it is insipid. I tend to buy indie and sale games that spark my interest. I love trying different games to find ones I like, but a lot of them I don't fall in love with and I am ok with that. If you want to invest some effort then look at my library, my reviews, and what I have spent time playing, then decide.

Posted: September 21, 2014
												A 2D side-scroller of sorts, S&S:EP tells the story of a rather unremarkable character known only as the Scythian, who goes on a journey to capture three Trigon pieces and offer up the Megatome at the summit of a mountain.Let me start by noting immediately that the production value is definitely up there. The visuals and especially the soundtrack are top-notch and definitely a major selling point of the game. The story is weaker and nothing spectacular, but definitely acceptable.Where the game gets questionable is, well, the gameplay. It is not bad per se, but a lot of features in this game can be considered quite frustrating, from the mundane (tedious walking in between places) to the estoric (why do puzzles depend on real-life moon phases?). S&S:EP aims to be unique, and it seems that one will either find the gameplay brilliant and refreshing, or pretentious and merely annoying as hell.For this reason, if at all possible, my recommendation: try before you buy - this is not a game for everyone, not even a majority. I hesitantly list this as a "yes", but only because even in the absence of good gameplay, you can have a few pretty scenes and nice music for your money.

Posted: April 27, 2013
												With the plethora of indie garbage floating around, there's very few titles that really stand out as being memorable. Sword & Sworcery EP is definitely one of those titles that stands out. It's a musical journey with epic gameplay, storytelling, sound effects, and music. I can't praise the sound effects and music enough--they make everything come together in spectacular fashion--it's gaming nirvana.Graphic-wise, the game isn't much to look at, but if you've ever played the original King's Quest, it's just an amazing throw-back to that era. Overall, Sword & Sworcery EP is a stunning adventure, both nostalgic and modern.

Posted: February 3, 2013
												The premise is a puzzle based point and click, but it uses some very cool imagery and scenery to form many of the puzzles in the game. There is also a real world/dream world dynamic, where actions in the dream world effect the story and puzzles of the real world. It's a very surreal game that really makes you want to keep exploring it; and while the setting and retro graphics seem simple on the surface, the wonder and mystery of the world is not something you will have encountered before. I can see this game not being for everyone, as at times it can be a little slow and the 'next step' can be a little vague and require lots of wandering to figure out. I see this as a normal part of an adventure game and wasn't put off by it, but would understand if anyone had issues with it. If you have this game in your library, pop it on some evening where you just want a relaxed game night :)

Posted: January 13, 2016
												Despite its relative age among other games (about five years as of writing this, counting the original iPad/iPhone release), Superbrothers: Sword & Sworcery EP maintains an air of timelessness. Between its unique visuals, haunting tunes, and brief but legendary story, Sword & Sworcery EP remains a game that should, and likely will, be played again and again for years to come.Thrust with little to no explanation into the boots of the Scythian, Sword & Sworcery EP tasks you with recovering the tools necessary to thwart an ancient evil. It's not entirely clear just how happily the Scythian's tale will end, but it's clear it must be ended, one way or another. Despite taking place in a relatively small slice of a world, the environment reflects your progress, sometimes in great ways, sometimes more subtly, goading you silently on toward success. The subtle nature of said guidance often leaves the game feeling a bit confusing and the player wandering, to be fair. However, a careful eye and/or ear is often the key to overcoming obstacles, and if nothing else, just try everything.It doesn't help that the game's social media integration is far less effective now that the game is hardly new. Back during its release, progress reports and hints flowed somewhat steadily onto Twitter, as sent out by the game as players made headway. Now, that trickle has all but stopped, making a look or two at a guide to the game a necessary evil, albeit a forgivable one. This sort of integration with the real world was an interesting experiment, however, as was the game's recognition of our world's moon phases, as based on your system's date settings. If you can, try and complete the game without messing around with your clock; it feels more rewarding to have done so legitimately, with time to think about things between sessions.The game does quite a bit with a rather simple interface as well. Inputs are rather basic, which is to be expected given it was originally created for iOS devices before finding its way to the PC. Still, the timing-based action sequences can offer a bit of a challenge, as can finding the right paths to traverse between said segments.Superbrothers: Sword & Sworcery EP flexes what many would consider the definition of a "game," but does so deftly, and leaves the player with a unique experience to remember. Be it the melodies of the soundtrack or what the art direction was able to do with a fairly limited style, there's something for everyone to remember this by.

												Probably even better on a tablet but well ported to the PC, Sword and Sworcery EP is a bit of an art game that should be enjoyed with a nice glass of Merlot and a laid-back disposition. Posted: January 31, 2014
												The art style is really pretty and reminiscent of older point-n-click adventure games like The Dig or Loom, maybe with a little Out of This World thrown in.  It's not as cartoony as other games of the time like Monkey Island or Day of the Tentacle.  The controls are a little weird and there are a lot of musical undertones connecting everything together which is what makes this game fresh.  Couple that with odd pseudo-intellectual psychobabble storytelling and the game does a nice job of holding one's interest, if only from the mystery.If I had to say anything negative, the controls are a bit...  counter-intuitive, and take awhile to learn but until then I found myself (and still do at times) randomly doing things with the mouse before I end up making what I want happen.  The action is rather minimalistic and a bit disjointed from the rest of the game, but it still remains fun, if not challenging at times.  Most of the game is along the lines of an interactive story, so the combat is kind of neat, not really seen in a point-n-click game like this before.As for the storytelling, I'm not sure what to say about it, other than I'm still on the fence.  The authors either wrote it to be extremely pretentious and artsy; or it's so convoluted with large vocabulary on purpose as to be an ironic means of giving the player little information while trying to remain vague and mysterious.  If it's the former, I'd rather not have any dialogue, because why say it when you can show it?  If it's the latter, they constantly break this rule by changing the writing style to be as blunt and directly open as possible at times, so you almost end up realizing that when small words are used it might be a real hint and you should pay some attention.  It makes the game come across like there are two or even three writers competing with each other as to how the game flows.  I think with just a little more work they could have done the entire game with no dialogue whatsoever, because the backgrounds, things, and musical sounds throughout the game change depending on what you're doing to them.  Then there's a weird "feature" where the game wants to tweet on your behalf to twitter.  I read that there's no point to this, so I guess it's just a blatant way of hyping up the game, which is kind of interesting, but if there's no reward then why do it?If you liked older point-n-click adventure games or used to slobber over everything Lucasarts, Tim Schafer, or Ron Gilbert pumped out in the '90s you'll enjoy this game.  It doesn't feel stale and it really does a great job of making you believe the world of the game exists, and you find yourself wondering how neat it would be to actually be there, wandering around exploring.

Posted: February 8, 2014
												This game stinks of hipster tryhard-i-ness. I bought it with the Humble Bundle V. I never thought to play it until now since I was sort of off put by the intentionally pixelated graphics. At first I thought, "hey this game isn't so bad, it feels like a sort of DMT-zelda". Then I realized, it literally is a terribly designed zelda game on acid with pretty music and admittedly well done graphics.The game is pretty minimalistic for PC, which only made more sense when I discovered it's an ipad game. And yet, the character dialogue basically hammers you in the face with "THIS IS WHAT WE'RE TRYING TO SAY WIHTOUT SUBTLETY." The dialogue seems like it was written by two hipsters part way through their degrees at Evergreen, too. Don't use "mirite?" in a dialogue, EVER.There's one part where the game's narrator tells you that the game's built-in twitter functionality (kill me now) may or may not play some role in one act, while the FAQ I was following said it does not. The game not only berates you time to time to tweet inane things that are happening which no one would get in the first place, but blatantly #lies to you in order to get you to advertise their game for free. For shame.The part that really drove me over the edge was a puzzle that involves actually waiting a week (or more!) for the right time to continue the story. ♥♥♥♥ this. I play games on my own time, not the developer's. The FAQ's solution was to change the date/time on my computer to fool the game (which then labels you as a cheater and makes it impossible to get a 100% rating). I tried moving the date by one day for a week both forwards and backwards from my current day with no result. What a waste of time. I've never been pushed to the edge to just straight up quit a game forever before.This game feels like an okay concept that was then designed by people who have a huge ego and a bizarre idea of what a game should be. I really can't believe this was bundled alongside Bastion, Limbo, Amnesia, and Psychonauts. Abysmal.

												My first impressions of Superbrothers: Sword & Sworcery EP...I played through the first "session" and it was fun. It serves it's purpose.  Some people's reviews stated there wasn't much to do, but it's not that bad.  It's a small adventure (so far), but I have a feeling it will become a larger one once I get deeper into the game.Completing the first session was fun and I am only 17% done with the game.  It took about 30 minutes and I didn't go everywhere I could.  The story was cool and I suspect it isn't over yet!  I think I just opened a can of worms so to speak! lolAnyway, I got this on sale so I can recommend buying it at sale price, but I am not sure about full price yet… I'll let you know when I finish the game! :-)  So far it runs great and have not had any problems on my iMac! :-)Here are my system specifications: iMac, i5 Quad-Core Intel processor 3.1GHZ, AMD Radeon HD 6970M with 1GB dedicated video RAM, 4GB system RAM, 1TB hard drive running OS X version 10.6.8, Journaled HFS+ Extended file system.

Posted: April 27, 2013
												With the plethora of indie garbage floating around, there's very few titles that really stand out as being memorable. Sword & Sworcery EP is definitely one of those titles that stands out. It's a musical journey with epic gameplay, storytelling, sound effects, and music. I can't praise the sound effects and music enough--they make everything come together in spectacular fashion--it's gaming nirvana.Graphic-wise, the game isn't much to look at, but if you've ever played the original King's Quest, it's just an amazing throw-back to that era. Overall, Sword & Sworcery EP is a stunning adventure, both nostalgic and modern.

Posted: February 3, 2013
												The premise is a puzzle based point and click, but it uses some very cool imagery and scenery to form many of the puzzles in the game. There is also a real world/dream world dynamic, where actions in the dream world effect the story and puzzles of the real world. It's a very surreal game that really makes you want to keep exploring it; and while the setting and retro graphics seem simple on the surface, the wonder and mystery of the world is not something you will have encountered before. I can see this game not being for everyone, as at times it can be a little slow and the 'next step' can be a little vague and require lots of wandering to figure out. I see this as a normal part of an adventure game and wasn't put off by it, but would understand if anyone had issues with it. If you have this game in your library, pop it on some evening where you just want a relaxed game night :)

Posted: July 30, 2013
												Really something special. Clever, interesting and amazing aesthetic supported by a great soundtrack. It can be pretty mystifying at times and test your patience, but it's kinda the whole point. S:S&S EP thrives off its mysteries and esoteric puzzles.S:S&S EP really makes the most of less is more, a minimalist UI, just enough exposition to fill out the world, but leave room for wonder, and a measured tempo to let you enjoy and take notice of the small things.Best of all, paradoxically, it feels nostalgic while still feeling like something new. You get the sense while playing, that the people behind this game were moved by certain games from days past. For me, it's a pretty heartwarming experience, I got a real sense of the kind of joy and fond feelings these people must have felt for their influences.And really, that's what this game is about. It's about the kind of things you, the player, will go through. The kind of emotions you'll experience as you explore. It's all about you and the game's not shy about addressing you directly to reinforce this. If you can suspend your disbelief a little, you'll love this game. Not disbelief of the story, but your own cynicism.Believe.And if music be the food of love, play on.

Posted: May 30, 2012
												Sword & Sworcery is a fantastic adventure game, with amazing graphics and sounds, breathtaking atmosphere and subtle storytelling. It is nothing like you ever played before, and probably never will be. It kidnaps you into a world of myths and dreams, so the only thing you have to bring with you while playing this is time and patience. Some puzzles might be a bit hard to see through, but ultimately what really counts in this game is the gaming experience itself. It creates an amazing atmosphere with so little material: the art, the animations, the sounds and the soundtrack and the story just fit perfectly together to create an impressive experience you won't forget that easy.So, if you search for a game which is simple, yet perfect and you enjoy subtle graphics and atmosphere then you should play this gem. Cause that's what it is, a gem.

Posted: January 28, 2016
												Superbrothers: Sword & Sworcery EP is a point-and-click adventure in which you are "the Scythian", a girl-warrior that has to find her way through ancient legends, shadows, dreams and reality, with help from a couple of people and "dogfella" (bark, bark). The game fully "shines" in its 8-bit graphics: this makes it "old-fashioned" compared to current games but this is part of the beauty of the game itself. You'll love or hate the graphical part: I loved it.    The music helps a lot in providing the right atmosphere for each part of the game. I discovered Jim Guthrie by playing at Sound Shapes on PSVita: the music here is very similar and enjoiable. On the negative side, there are moments in the game where you feel lost and the next objectives (or how to achieve them) are not 100% clear. This happens especially if you put away the game for few days.At the end I felt ... sad ... in finishing the game. If a game can raise this kind of emotions by putting together few pixels,well, the objective is reached. Overall I definitely recommend this game, but this cannot be valid for anyone approaching this game.

Posted: December 1, 2012
												This game is realy funky.  I mean, on a completely superfluous level, it's gorgeous.  The sprite art and scenery is so simple but so decorative and detailed.  It's an amazing look.  And Jim Guthrie's music is just the best part about the whole game.  I've never fallen in love with a game's music faster than I have with Superbrothers.The gameplay is hit and miss for me.  I liked the exploration aspect, but the puzzles are usually far from tricky and the combat is clearly made for touch-screen devices like Android of iOS.  The three Trigon "boss fights" are also all basically the same, and considering those are some of the only enemies you encounter in the game, it would have been nice to see some creativity.  That being said, I would imagine they wanted as little combat as possible, so maybe that's why?  I dunno.As I mentioned, the exploration is pretty awesome.  You get dragged into the atmosphere so quickly because of the beautiful visuals and music.  And there are so many things you interact with and the Megatome's constant "thought journal" is just brilliant.  The "Lunar Cycle" system is also interesting for sure, and I kind of like how the entire game is kind of focused more on the "spiritual experience" it's trying to offer you.  It's unorthodox but very welcomed.The characters are all very fleshed out, and the narrator herself is charming and witty.  You really feel for her by the end of the journey because...well, I can't spoil but it 's some pretty heavy stuff.  The story isn't too explicit, but unlike titles like Limbo which left me wanting a lot more, Superbrothers just barely manages to quench the thirst.  I don't need to know more...I can simple assume and I'm totally fine with that.Honestly, I'd recommend Superbrothers if you got it in the Humble Bundle or if you can just grab it for cheap.  You can beat it in four or five hours or so, but you'll probably go back and play it a few times just because it's actually impossible to see everything in the first playthrough.  The music and visuals are worth the purchase on their own, so check this out if you want something different but very, very interesting.

Posted: May 3, 2013
												I had pretty high expectations for this game and it mostly delivered.  The gameplay itself is pretty basic: movement is done by double clicking a place on the screen and combat has only two buttons (attack or block).   Most of the odd controls are due to the game being an iOS port, but beyond the odd phrasing of the tutorial the controls are pretty decent.  The game gets better when it starts giving you puzzles: early on you unlock the power to "sing" and can interact with the environment to progress.  Mostly this boils down to clicking on the screen like a maniac until you figure out the order of things to press but there are few times where the game actually surprises you beyond the cookie-cutter puzzles that are introduced at the start of the game.  However, the story more than makes up for the decent gameplay.  The game presents you with a fairly original fantasy universe where most of the lore is told in the background.  Once you finish the first act, you gain access to a device that allows you to see what other characters think about the events going on; this gives more lore and occasionally hints about how to progress.  Our universe's lingo mixes in occasionally: words like "upload" find their way into the dialogue and help create a mix of fantasy and contemporary.  The game surprised me with its unique sense of humor as well; the game is narrated in first person and this often leads to humorous self-revelations.  The game is a visual treat with its stylized and elongated pixel characters and rich backgrounds.  Of course the music is also incredible: the game was made with the music in mind and it shows.  The game took me around 4.5 hours, which is decently long for a cheap indie game.  It doesn’t lend itself to be replayed, although there are a few easter eggs you may miss on your first run through.  The game splits itself into 4 parts; the third part notably takes a whole lunar month to complete (unless you are a cheater).  I suggest you follow the game’s recommendation to take a break between acts; it helps break the sometimes repetitive gameplay.  Overall, it’s worth the asking price and is for sure a buy if it goes on sale for $5 or less.

Posted: May 25, 2015
												Superbrothers: Sword & Sworcery EP is a unique game (if it can be called a game). It's more of an experience? The main focus is not the game itself but the pixel art and the clever use of sound and music. The music always matches the mood of the action giving you upbeat and epic tunes during battles and soft ambient tunes during exploration. In fact, battles were my favorite parts of the game (though there were few). They battles are simple patterns of attack and defense but they still prove to be fun and sometimes a bit intense. While there are some definite good aspects of this game, there are other aspects that have me torn and make this game somewhat difficult to recommend. First of all, when playing this game, you have to remember that it was intended for mobile devices and tablets. I didn't understand that at first and was instantly frustrated with the controls. Touching and tapping has been replaced with mouse controls. It's still a bit confusing but you get used to it. My second gripe is that you as a player have very little idea of who your character is, what she is doing, and why (you understand more towards the end but for most of the game, you will be confused). It's important to check your surroundings, interact with characters, and listen to what they say (though they can be deliberately cryptic at times). This bring me to my next complaint... This game works fine, it looks good but there was something that kept bothering me and I couldn't quite figure it out until a couple of other users pointed it out in their own reviews. The game feels pretentious. Something about the overall presentation... The flashing of the game's title every now and then in-game, the flowery language of the archetype narrator, the fact that your character is known a "The Scythian" while other characters get names like "Logfella"... It's difficult to place the blame on one aspect but something is not quite right about this game's overall atmosphere. Overall, this is not a bad game. And maybe I'm wrong and this atmosphere was not the intention of the game's developers. So if you're into point-and-click, adventure, and music type things... Then give Sword & Sworcery a try and decide for yourself. It's a unique experience that you won't find elsewhere.

												My first impressions of Superbrothers: Sword & Sworcery EP...I played through the first "session" and it was fun. It took about 30 minutes and I didn't go everywhere I could.  The story was cool and I suspect it isn't over yet!  I think I just opened a can of worms so to speak! lolAnyway, I got this on sale so I can recommend buying it at sale price, but I am not sure about full price yet… I'll let you know when I finish the game! :-)  So far it runs great and have not had any problems on my iMac! :-)Here are my system specifications: iMac, i5 Quad-Core Intel processor 3.1GHZ, AMD Radeon HD 6970M with 1GB dedicated video RAM, 4GB system RAM, 1TB hard drive running OS X version 10.6.8, Journaled HFS+ Extended file system.

Posted: August 26, 2014
												Music: The soundtrack. The soundtrack the soundtrack the soundtrack. Soundtrack? The. Soundtrack.Sound Effects: I don't think I have ever commented on sound effects. I mean, voice acting, sure, but that to me is its own category. I also want to cater my chatter to the games themselves since oftentimes something stands out on its own and needs to be talked about. That said, the sound effects are crisp, elegant, real, magical. I think crisp is a delicious word; it makes me happy. Crisp. That was the first thing I thought of when I watched the Steam Release video. It carries throughout the game. Moments where there is little music are made vibrant by the sound effects. Not an "oh I hear birds, how realistic" or "oh the people in the distant market, I can hear them!" vibrancy. It goes deeper into an almost trance inducing simplistic beauty. It dances in your mind. It dances with your mind.Story: Simple. At least to me it wasn't terribly deep, but I admit that I didn't spend an enormous amount of time in the game. The writing is superb though. I was pulled into the mystery of the game mostly becasue I didn't feel I had to be playing the game to be a part of it. The story became part of my own. The woeful errand is mine.Gameplay (A): The controls and actual gameplay are brutally straightforward and it works. I felt good about accomplishing things but it was more of an "Ah-ha! Got it!" feeling than an "I did it! I can't believe it! YEEEEAAAAHHHH!" feeling. That said, the last part of the game gives you the latter feeling.Gameplay (B): The way it incorporates into life would have been more engaging if I used twitter. Still, this game got me to actually make a twitter account, so that was something. I haven't used twitter since, so...yeah. Anywho, even despite that element being wasted on this guy I found the way this ties into the real world to be the best thing ever. I am sure some people will think it is lame, but I loved it. I don't want to ruin it, you can always look it up if you want, but it is astronomy related. Nothing complex. Nothing you can't google your way into knowing. But I was enraptured.Graphics: Obviously not for everyone. I loved them. It manages to be pixel art while also being art. Not all pixel art games are terribly pretty, but this one is. Nostalgia doesn't even have much to do with it. It is an art style and I love what they have done with it.Overall: I bought it, obviously. I watched the release trailer and knew I had to. I am recommending it. I bought the soundtrack. I fell in love with the mystery and ambiance of this game. You could read a hundred reviews that say this is amazing and you may think it is insipid. I tend to buy indie and sale games that spark my interest. I love trying different games to find ones I like, but a lot of them I don't fall in love with and I am ok with that. If you want to invest some effort then look at my library, my reviews, and what I have spent time playing, then decide.

Posted: May 3, 2014
												Wow... I owned this game for a long time before playing it. I had no idea what I was missing out on. Great retro adventure game, with an interesting story that isn't shoved down the players throat. The player is thrown into a world s/he knows nothing about, in a game where the mechanics are not explained by some boring tutorial or lame on-screen directions. Posted: May 6, 2014
												Superbrothers: Sword & Sworcery EP is one of the best games I have played this year. It's blend of lush, beautiful pixel art, engrossing sound effects and score, and intuitve gameplay sets the bar for indie games several pegs higher.Although the gameplay mechanics are designed for touch-enabled devices, I had no issues using a mouse to click, drag, and strum my way though game. The combat system was probably easier on touch, but I only encountered a few mis-clicks in my five-and-a-half hour playthrough.I believe it would be very easy for someone to beat this game for the first time in four hours, but I managed to get turned around a few times, especially in Session 3. The characters generally guide you along well enough to your next goal, though the hints can be quite cryptic at times. When I did finally find my way again, it was only then that I realized the true meaning.At its core, the indiekid/hipster vibe of this game will either make or break the experience for you. The vocal tracks, few and far between, remind me of more of a spaced-out Bill and Ted than one would expect from a game, and both the developers and sound/music guy Jim Guthrie managed to have cameos. I found these traits endearing, the final polish on an already unblemished game. If you find yourself allergic to alliteration (or pretentiousness), then you might have a hard time with this one.

Posted: January 20, 2014
												For minimum disappointment, S:S&S EP should be treated, as its title suggests, as an Extended Play record. Expect a relatively passive experience, to be enjoyed multiple times, filled with sumptuous (and detailed) pixel art, lashings of style, a hint of story, as well as excellent and atmospheric music. What you shouldn't expect is a whole lot of interaction. Most of the time, you'll be exploring the world, figuring out where and how to advance the story.You may notice the sword and shield in some of the screen shots. Yes, there are battles, but there aren't many of them. Don't come into this thinking it's some kind of action RPG. It's most certainly not. It's a game about exploration and atmosphere. If you treat it this way, you won't be disappointed.

Posted: May 3, 2013
												I had pretty high expectations for this game and it mostly delivered.  The gameplay itself is pretty basic: movement is done by double clicking a place on the screen and combat has only two buttons (attack or block).   Most of the odd controls are due to the game being an iOS port, but beyond the odd phrasing of the tutorial the controls are pretty decent.  The game gets better when it starts giving you puzzles: early on you unlock the power to "sing" and can interact with the environment to progress.  Mostly this boils down to clicking on the screen like a maniac until you figure out the order of things to press but there are few times where the game actually surprises you beyond the cookie-cutter puzzles that are introduced at the start of the game.  However, the story more than makes up for the decent gameplay.  The game presents you with a fairly original fantasy universe where most of the lore is told in the background.  Once you finish the first act, you gain access to a device that allows you to see what other characters think about the events going on; this gives more lore and occasionally hints about how to progress.  Our universe's lingo mixes in occasionally: words like "upload" find their way into the dialogue and help create a mix of fantasy and contemporary.  The game surprised me with its unique sense of humor as well; the game is narrated in first person and this often leads to humorous self-revelations.  The game is a visual treat with its stylized and elongated pixel characters and rich backgrounds.  Of course the music is also incredible: the game was made with the music in mind and it shows.  The game took me around 4.5 hours, which is decently long for a cheap indie game.  It doesn’t lend itself to be replayed, although there are a few easter eggs you may miss on your first run through.  The game splits itself into 4 parts; the third part notably takes a whole lunar month to complete (unless you are a cheater).  I suggest you follow the game’s recommendation to take a break between acts; it helps break the sometimes repetitive gameplay.  Overall, it’s worth the asking price and is for sure a buy if it goes on sale for $5 or less.

Posted: February 8, 2014
												This game stinks of hipster tryhard-i-ness. I bought it with the Humble Bundle V. I never thought to play it until now since I was sort of off put by the intentionally pixelated graphics. At first I thought, "hey this game isn't so bad, it feels like a sort of DMT-zelda". Then I realized, it literally is a terribly designed zelda game on acid with pretty music and admittedly well done graphics.The game is pretty minimalistic for PC, which only made more sense when I discovered it's an ipad game. And yet, the character dialogue basically hammers you in the face with "THIS IS WHAT WE'RE TRYING TO SAY WIHTOUT SUBTLETY." The dialogue seems like it was written by two hipsters part way through their degrees at Evergreen, too. Don't use "mirite?" in a dialogue, EVER.There's one part where the game's narrator tells you that the game's built-in twitter functionality (kill me now) may or may not play some role in one act, while the FAQ I was following said it does not. The game not only berates you time to time to tweet inane things that are happening which no one would get in the first place, but blatantly #lies to you in order to get you to advertise their game for free. For shame.The part that really drove me over the edge was a puzzle that involves actually waiting a week (or more!) for the right time to continue the story. ♥♥♥♥ this. I play games on my own time, not the developer's. The FAQ's solution was to change the date/time on my computer to fool the game (which then labels you as a cheater and makes it impossible to get a 100% rating). I tried moving the date by one day for a week both forwards and backwards from my current day with no result. What a waste of time. I've never been pushed to the edge to just straight up quit a game forever before.This game feels like an okay concept that was then designed by people who have a huge ego and a bizarre idea of what a game should be. I really can't believe this was bundled alongside Bastion, Limbo, Amnesia, and Psychonauts. Abysmal.

Posted: December 1, 2012
												This game is realy funky.  I mean, on a completely superfluous level, it's gorgeous.  The sprite art and scenery is so simple but so decorative and detailed.  It's an amazing look.  And Jim Guthrie's music is just the best part about the whole game.  I've never fallen in love with a game's music faster than I have with Superbrothers.The gameplay is hit and miss for me.  I liked the exploration aspect, but the puzzles are usually far from tricky and the combat is clearly made for touch-screen devices like Android of iOS.  The three Trigon "boss fights" are also all basically the same, and considering those are some of the only enemies you encounter in the game, it would have been nice to see some creativity.  That being said, I would imagine they wanted as little combat as possible, so maybe that's why?  I dunno.As I mentioned, the exploration is pretty awesome.  You get dragged into the atmosphere so quickly because of the beautiful visuals and music.  And there are so many things you interact with and the Megatome's constant "thought journal" is just brilliant.  The "Lunar Cycle" system is also interesting for sure, and I kind of like how the entire game is kind of focused more on the "spiritual experience" it's trying to offer you.  It's unorthodox but very welcomed.The characters are all very fleshed out, and the narrator herself is charming and witty.  You really feel for her by the end of the journey because...well, I can't spoil but it 's some pretty heavy stuff.  The story isn't too explicit, but unlike titles like Limbo which left me wanting a lot more, Superbrothers just barely manages to quench the thirst.  I don't need to know more...I can simple assume and I'm totally fine with that.Honestly, I'd recommend Superbrothers if you got it in the Humble Bundle or if you can just grab it for cheap.  You can beat it in four or five hours or so, but you'll probably go back and play it a few times just because it's actually impossible to see everything in the first playthrough.  The music and visuals are worth the purchase on their own, so check this out if you want something different but very, very interesting.

Posted: June 22, 2014
												Here's the deal: I liked this game. Yeah, it's a mobile game ported to PC and that does mean it isn't technically flawless. But man, I remember staying up in a room with no air conditioning in the middle of summer playing it and being like...two hours late for something because I wanted to finish this in one sitting.  I think I was meeting Mike for something. Mike, I'm sorry. On the whole it's a really well made and fun adventure game that does a fantastic job at telling its story in a world that's filled to bursting with mysterious and enticing tone. The whole experience is truly evocative; a quest that will somehow lead you straight to peril, a la Shadow of the Colossus. The story itself is compelling and the game does a wonderful job of doing as much storytelling through the beautifully realized environments and haunting sound design as it does through actual text. And here's the cool thing about that. Sword and Sworcery swings almost all of its weight in those departments to create an engrossing experience. Why do I care about the world? Because it's simultaneously beautiful and enticing, it beckons for you to explore it. How do I know it's not just goofy? Because the music and the design of each area inform you of the mood there, you can tell when you're supposed to chuckle and when you're supposed to be on edge. Why do you press on? Because it looks like a quest-y video game, what else would you do?Where does it fall apart? That's why I want you to play it. Personally, I think the narrator breaking things up is a bit to cheeky for the tone of the game (at least as I remember it almost a year later). Yeah, some of the combat controls are a little wonky, yeah the movement can be a teeny bit frustrating. But really, I want you to play this. I want you to understand what good design is: bringing all aspects of the experience together to create something that you want to spend time with, characters you feel for even if you don't know them well, and provide you with a story that you remember vividly enough to tell your little nephew at a camping trip 6 months after finishing it. It'll provide you with that wide-eyed childlike joy of exploration and the bittersweet joy of completion. If this does convince you to buy the game, message me after it's done. I want to talk about it. So bad.

Posted: May 6, 2014
												Superbrothers: Sword & Sworcery EP is one of the best games I have played this year. It's blend of lush, beautiful pixel art, engrossing sound effects and score, and intuitve gameplay sets the bar for indie games several pegs higher.Although the gameplay mechanics are designed for touch-enabled devices, I had no issues using a mouse to click, drag, and strum my way though game. The combat system was probably easier on touch, but I only encountered a few mis-clicks in my five-and-a-half hour playthrough.I believe it would be very easy for someone to beat this game for the first time in four hours, but I managed to get turned around a few times, especially in Session 3. The characters generally guide you along well enough to your next goal, though the hints can be quite cryptic at times. When I did finally find my way again, it was only then that I realized the true meaning.At its core, the indiekid/hipster vibe of this game will either make or break the experience for you. The vocal tracks, few and far between, remind me of more of a spaced-out Bill and Ted than one would expect from a game, and both the developers and sound/music guy Jim Guthrie managed to have cameos. I found these traits endearing, the final polish on an already unblemished game. If you find yourself allergic to alliteration (or pretentiousness), then you might have a hard time with this one.

Posted: July 3, 2014
												Superbrothers: Sword & Sworcery EP is one of those unique gems that just plain works. The art direction is both bizarre and beautiful, and the soundtrack is one of the best I have ever heard in gaming. The story is so simple yet insanely deep, and the ending is one to think about for a long time. Although it is a short 4-hour campaign, it is very much a deeper game than the majority of AAA games on the market. Superbrothers is just plain brilliant. But on the flip side, the controls are pretty bad on PC/Mac. Unfortunately, the game was original designed and released on iOS, and it suffers in transition. Moving the screen around, zooming in and zooming out, and combat are all much more complicated with the mouse than with touch screen. But despite the bad controls, this is very much a worthy investment and one of the most unique and powerful indie games I have ever played. Definitely a recommend!

Posted: April 5, 2013
												This game.THIS GAME.This game is very very good.(I don't have a sense to whether these are minor or major spoilers, but it think of it as minor spoilers.)This game takes gives you the experience of traversing a small land.A land you never thought you'd see when you loaded up this game.A land not so different from your own.A land full of lush forest, soothing sounds, and a journey you'll remember to the ends of your days....and in the end, you'll be left heartbroken. miserable. This game puts your mind on an emotional rollercoaster. What you think is the core goal. That thing, that you keep working towards and working towards is always getting closer, but do you really want to continue?The answer is yes. Obviously.But then you watch, as your friend, this character that you grow attached to, this character that charmed you over with her third-person, cynical style. This Scythian girl who wants only to rid herself of this new horror that torments her, and seal away that which she can't deal with...You watch as she slowly fades.This girl who wants the same goal as you. Watch as you lead her through fight after fight, leading her closer to your mutual goal. And she fades. Her health is but a secondary note as you fight to your ultimate goal.But is it really worth it? Is it really worth sacrificing the life of this girl to seal what could be this eternal monster that haunts her forever? Do you wan't to watch her through every moment of her everlasting agony, as she's injured, diseased, and physically destroyed from your escapades to rid her of her problem?Well, I guess that's really your decision. Isn't it?

Posted: June 22, 2014
												Here's the deal: I liked this game. Yeah, it's a mobile game ported to PC and that does mean it isn't technically flawless. But man, I remember staying up in a room with no air conditioning in the middle of summer playing it and being like...two hours late for something because I wanted to finish this in one sitting.  I think I was meeting Mike for something. Mike, I'm sorry. On the whole it's a really well made and fun adventure game that does a fantastic job at telling its story in a world that's filled to bursting with mysterious and enticing tone. The whole experience is truly evocative; a quest that will somehow lead you straight to peril, a la Shadow of the Colossus. The story itself is compelling and the game does a wonderful job of doing as much storytelling through the beautifully realized environments and haunting sound design as it does through actual text. And here's the cool thing about that. Sword and Sworcery swings almost all of its weight in those departments to create an engrossing experience. Why do I care about the world? Because it's simultaneously beautiful and enticing, it beckons for you to explore it. How do I know it's not just goofy? Because the music and the design of each area inform you of the mood there, you can tell when you're supposed to chuckle and when you're supposed to be on edge. Why do you press on? Because it looks like a quest-y video game, what else would you do?Where does it fall apart? That's why I want you to play it. Personally, I think the narrator breaking things up is a bit to cheeky for the tone of the game (at least as I remember it almost a year later). Yeah, some of the combat controls are a little wonky, yeah the movement can be a teeny bit frustrating. But really, I want you to play this. I want you to understand what good design is: bringing all aspects of the experience together to create something that you want to spend time with, characters you feel for even if you don't know them well, and provide you with a story that you remember vividly enough to tell your little nephew at a camping trip 6 months after finishing it. It'll provide you with that wide-eyed childlike joy of exploration and the bittersweet joy of completion. If this does convince you to buy the game, message me after it's done. I want to talk about it. So bad.

Posted: May 30, 2012
												Sword & Sworcery is a fantastic adventure game, with amazing graphics and sounds, breathtaking atmosphere and subtle storytelling. It is nothing like you ever played before, and probably never will be. It kidnaps you into a world of myths and dreams, so the only thing you have to bring with you while playing this is time and patience. Some puzzles might be a bit hard to see through, but ultimately what really counts in this game is the gaming experience itself. It creates an amazing atmosphere with so little material: the art, the animations, the sounds and the soundtrack and the story just fit perfectly together to create an impressive experience you won't forget that easy.So, if you search for a game which is simple, yet perfect and you enjoy subtle graphics and atmosphere then you should play this gem. Cause that's what it is, a gem.

Posted: October 25, 2013
												This game is a prime example of "game as art". While it does not pose a real challenge, especially to seasoned gamers, it presents a beautifully crafted hero's story with philosophical or artistic meaning behind nearly every decision made by its creators.Gameplay is particularly intuitive for touch devices and the player has only a few controls to deal with throughout the game. I can understand that players seeking a much more conventional gaming experience are disappointed very early on into S&S. However, if you're willing to try something that deviates from the conventional and provides a rich and enjoyable story with compelling sound and visuals, play this game.

Posted: July 30, 2013
												Really something special. Clever, interesting and amazing aesthetic supported by a great soundtrack. It can be pretty mystifying at times and test your patience, but it's kinda the whole point. S:S&S EP thrives off its mysteries and esoteric puzzles.S:S&S EP really makes the most of less is more, a minimalist UI, just enough exposition to fill out the world, but leave room for wonder, and a measured tempo to let you enjoy and take notice of the small things.Best of all, paradoxically, it feels nostalgic while still feeling like something new. You get the sense while playing, that the people behind this game were moved by certain games from days past. For me, it's a pretty heartwarming experience, I got a real sense of the kind of joy and fond feelings these people must have felt for their influences.And really, that's what this game is about. It's about the kind of things you, the player, will go through. The kind of emotions you'll experience as you explore. It's all about you and the game's not shy about addressing you directly to reinforce this. If you can suspend your disbelief a little, you'll love this game. Not disbelief of the story, but your own cynicism.Believe.And if music be the food of love, play on.

												If you want to play a relaxing adventure game at a leisurly pace then check this out. Posted: August 19, 2015
												Superbrothers: Sword & Sworcery EP is a simple and quirky mouse-driven adventure game with an excellent soundtrack and deceptively captivating art style. There's really not much else to say when it comes to this game. This game does not overstay its welcome and does an excellent job of setting the player on a vague adventure through a forest where they must find magical triangles for no clearly defined purpose. This game's humor is extremely self-aware, and is often juxtaposed by the game's sense of epic art direction. Speaking of the art, it's hard to hide that this game uses a sprite based style that is actually more impressive than you might first think. Animations are extremely fluid, and you'll find yourself captivated by pixel art that looks fairly mediocre in stills yet springs to life in motion. More important than anything else is this game's atmosphere and theme. This game has a wonderful soundtrack that plays many nature-inspired tunes while you walk around solving nature-inspired puzzles in your quest to find the magical Trigon. It's a difficult feeling to describe, which is why I have to recommend feeling it firsthand. There's something very earthy about the way this game presents itself.However, if I had to find pick one gripe about this game it'd be the "Moon Mood" system in Session III. Regardless of how you decide to manipulate this game to utilize it, a gameplay-based way and system manipulation-based way", the process is tedious and puts an unnecessary damper on the game's overall pace. However, it is a minor gripe when the rest of the game is so captivating.Overall it's extremely easy to recommend this game. If you're looking for a relaxing puzzle-adventure game with an excellent soundtrack this is an easy must buy! Especially when it's on sale!

Posted: June 23, 2012
												Whether one considers S&S a point and click is debatable. It's a highly linear adventure somewhat similar in style to old Sierra or Lucasarts point and clicks, but with much simplified/absent point & click puzzles and QTE-like pattern solving puzzles instead. It's much better than that sounds, though. What the game does right is possess extraordinary art in a (now-characteristic) minimalist, pixel-stringent art style and easily the best soundtrack of any game ever (better than VVVVVV and Earthbound, even!). The wonderful art caters to a retro-game aesthetic with loving detail that I'm big a fan of, and the music by Jim Guthrie is complex and atmospheric and calming without being elevator music. The soundtrack even stands on its own after the game is long over.

												I was intrigued by the trailer I saw in the Humble Indie Bundle, and a friend of mine picked this title up for me. I would have gladly paid full price for it if I could have. In short, this is an absolute gem of a game. The music is absolutely wonderful, and it engages you with the gameplay. The plot (such as it is) and the art style might not be for everyone, but if you enjoy throwback to pixel-era graphcis and vague mystery men pushing you in the right direction to save a world in your own woeful tale (ahem, Half Life 2), I do believe you'll get a kick out of this one.It's also short (insofar in that it can be beaten in a month - less if you 'cheat'), so it's a nice title to hold you over until the bigger releases arrive.Really, just pick this up. It's utterly fantastic and absolutely worth your time.
